The speaker acknowledges their own influence and positions of authority, while also recognizing the complexities and dualities of their role. The final line shows a sense of pride and patriotism with a nod to the United States.

Overall, these lyrics convey a sense of strength, resilience, and self-awareness, all while navigating various aspects of power and influence in society.

tite: Teriyaki Joe: Neo-Harlem Detective (Chapter Two: Coffee)
lyrics:
[November 30, 2013:]
Teriyaki Joe: Neo-Harlem Detective Chapter 2: 
Coffee


"You're Not Real Joe" God Damn hackers!
 They got into my 
MindPhone
 somehow.

They keep leaving these messages. 
Nobody is coming to get this junky. All his body parts are expired probably why he was getting doped up.

Two years ago he'd of been stripped clean before he hit the ground. But now designers parts are so easy to come by he's good as gum wrappers


Don't know why they shot him though. Cops these days. You never know. Disposal might come in a couple weeks. Might not.


Valentines Day. Hookers working overtime. Flower shop empty. Whole city in love with something or atleast pretending to be.


I step into the diner and work my way through the crowd waiting on tables to steal a seat at the counter. It's always a seat there.


5 coffees, 3 grits, 6 eggs, 2 toasts, 9 sausage.
 She hands over the 
glasses
. I inform her these are dirty. She doesn't care.

I wipe them on my jacket and put them on. 5 blinks equal 25 Units. She slides me the black tray with the pills and sneers out "Bon Apetite"


Units are stored in the eyes. Blinking releases Units into receiving glasses or goggles or contacts and your purchase is complete.


They updated the toast. Coffee is still terrible. I spot Tall Creole at the end of the counter popping back Gin pills raw. A reality freak.


I look back down with my eyes half over the top of the glasses
 & see the 
black tray in the glasses I see a plate overflowing with breakfast.


I like to stay one foot in & one foot out I guess. I can take being lied to. Being a liar comes easy too. Here its an expectation of sorts.

The human body still isn't used to digesting pill food properly. Updating is a constant to combat the side effects. Shakes, vomiting etc.


Better than real food though. That shit will kill you. So many additives and molecular advertising in it it's damn near plastic.


Tall Creole shakes violently, damn near falls off stool. She's almost ready 4 the night to take her. I hope she makes it out the other side.

I grab the Shake Handles connected to the stool and prepare for my turn. It comes. I wink a tip. Take off the glasses & head into the nite.

---1 Million Units Respond For Details--- glows in the left hand corner of my mind. I've been thinking about it this whole time.

Sounds like a set up to be honest. 1 Millions Units is the apple but who is the devil on the other side. I guess that makes me Adam. No Eve!

"Playback Tall Creole" half my mind rewinds back to my thick-legged tail as she followed me into the diner recording me as I recorded her.

Now we have our Eve, Adam & The Apple. Now we just need The Devil. Sometimes the best place to find the devil is in the mirror. Lets see.

---This is Teriyaki Joe...What Are The Details??---

*...END OF CHAPTER 2...*
summary:
The lyrics from Chapter 2 of Teriyaki Joe: Neo-Harlem Detective depict a dystopian society where technology and consumption have taken over human life. The protagonist, Teriyaki Joe, navigates through this world where food is consumed in the form of pills and bodies are easily replaceable with designer parts.

The theme of deception and illusion is prevalent in the lyrics, as Teriyaki Joe acknowledges that lies and falsehoods are part of everyday life in this society. The concept of reality is blurred, with people like Tall Creole indulging in reality-altering substances like Gin pills raw.

The reference to the apple in the phrase "1 Million Units Respond For Details" hints at temptation and possible danger, with Teriyaki Joe likening himself to Adam and Tall Creole to Eve. The idea of the devil lurking in the mirror suggests that the true dangers and threats may come from within oneself.

Overall, the lyrics highlight a world where technology, consumption, and deception have warped the idea of reality and where the characters navigate a landscape fraught with danger and uncertainty.

tite: Teriyaki Joe: Neo-Harlem Detective (Chapter Three: Gravy)
lyrics:
[December 2, 2013:]
Teriyaki Joe: Neo-Harlem Detective

Chapter 3: 
Gravy


---Download Complete--- Hmmm looks like I'll be heading upstairs.

The cab stinks. The stale intensity of so many burned out digital cigar cores left to decay on the floor. The acid graffiti. It doesn't fit.

Not fit transport for somebody 
"Going Upstairs" as they say.
 We all say that. 
Some champagne and classical music would be nice.


Maybe a chauffeur would give the trip up top a fancier sentiment. I mean the best of us should travel with a little more class and dignity.

This is like being in a port-o-potty with thrusters. A couple coughs. A well aimed spit. Yeah thats how the "Best Of Us" do it, precisely.

Up through the clouds. Directly into the Moon. We pass through it. It's only a meter thick. So warm. So fake. Color is still wrong to me.

The cab slows to a halt. Border patrol scans the ID tags. All clear. One step down. 
Disinfection nozzles spray the cab down.
 Missed a spot.


Step three is up next. Blindness. Total sensory disconnect. 3 seconds. 3 weeks. It's all the same in "non-sense." Helpless. Out of touch.


"EOJ LAER TON RUOY"
 --------- *digital sizzle"


----------------------—•----------------------------------------------------music-------------------------------------------------------


---------------!!! Awww Nice. Grass. Glass. Nothing else. Central Fucking Park Baby! It's all tai-chi and vegan techno utopia. Upstairs.

NH is Downstairs.
 Can't see it from here. 
Shit I wouldn't wanna see it either. Most these folks never have. Never will.
 Where's my devil?

Birthing out of Non-sense mode is always a mellow moment. Has to be or the shock would give you a heart attack. 
Wish I could smoke here.


Man would you look at that. The real Sun.
 Son of a bitch. My devil approaches. His name is 11. Mid level manager at a pill manufacturer.

I don't believe him. He's not my devil. Too many questions. He's just checking me out. He knows I know. He changes to his real voice.

All this espionage. Games. The real voice isn't really right either. Neither are the eyes. All tests. The "air" is thick with nano-machines

It's like wading in a pool of thin water. It's what moves things here. A seamless, all encompassing soup of nano-machines & information.

A spoonful of this stuff would sell for millions back Downstairs if we had real sunlight to keep it alive that is. 
What'd he say???!!!

"That's right Mr.Teriyaki (-It's Joe!-) I want you to bring my daughter back."


Impossible.
summary:
These lyrics seem to be describing a futuristic and dystopian world, where transportation, technology, and society are drastically different from what we know. The protagonist, Teriyaki Joe, is a detective navigating this strange world and interacting with different characters, such as the devil-like figure named 11.

Some major themes and metaphors that can be inferred from these lyrics include:

1. Class divide and social hierarchy: The contrast between the luxurious image of champagne and classical music, and the grimy reality of the cab suggests a divide between the elite and the lower class. This theme is further reinforced by the mention of Border patrol and the concept of "upstairs" and "downstairs."

2. Technology and surveillance: The mention of ID tags, disinfection nozzles, and sensory disconnect allude to a world where technology controls and monitors individuals at every level. The idea of a "non-sense mode" and the presence of nano-machines suggest a highly advanced and intrusive surveillance system.

3. Loss of humanity: The protagonist's interaction with 11, who changes his voice and appearance, highlights the theme of deception and the loss of authenticity in a world dominated by technology. The mention of the "real Sun" and the protagonist's disbelief in 11's request to bring back his daughter suggest a disconnect from emotions and human connections.

Overall, these lyrics paint a picture of a dark and chaotic world where individuals are trapped in a system of control and manipulation, struggling to maintain their humanity in the face of overwhelming technology.

summary:
The lyrics in this song by Lupe Fiasco touch on various themes such as the juxtaposition of different lifestyles, the allure of money and fame, the struggles of life in the trap, and the complexities of relationships and interactions in the world of fame and excess.

The first verse talks about the lavish lifestyle of celebrities and athletes, with references to luxury brands, flashy cars, and the allure of strip clubs and nightlife. The lyrics also touch on the transient nature of fame and money, as well as the pressures and dangers that come with living in that world.

The chorus highlights the contrast between the glamorous facade of success and the darker realities of the trap life. It speaks to the grind and hustle of making money in the streets, the temptation of easy money, and the consequences that come with that lifestyle.

The second verse delves deeper into the complexities of living a double life, where success in music or sports is intertwined with a past in the streets. It touches on the dichotomy of street credit versus mainstream success, and the conflicts that arise from trying to navigate both worlds.

Overall, the lyrics in this song paint a vivid picture of the contradictions, struggles, and temptations that come with living a life of fame, money, and hustle. It is a commentary on the highs and lows of chasing success, the sacrifices that have to be made, and the blurred lines between different worlds.

summary:
These lyrics seem to touch on a variety of themes such as religion, politics, capitalism, and personal struggles. The mention of a televangelist and references to faith and grace suggest a critique of organized religion and the ways in which it can be commercialized. The line about nuclear bombs and arms build up could be a commentary on the dangers of militarization and the pursuit of power.

The reference to European Union and Brexit could be seen as commentary on the political landscape and the tensions within regions. The comparison of the flow to EU and beats to Brexit could suggest a sense of disunity or discord within society.

The mention of Trump and his actions, such as pulling up to the pump with his trunks on backwards, could be seen as a critique of his leadership or decision-making. The comparison of him to being on acid and the reference to gas could imply a sense of chaos or unpredictability in his actions.

The mention of Iceland and its geothermal screens could symbolize a sense of warmth or healing in the midst of isolation or struggle. The metaphor of two chains, one ring could represent a sense of duality or conflict within oneself.

Overall, these lyrics seem to touch on themes of power, politics, personal struggles, and the search for peace or resolution in a chaotic world. The use of metaphors and imagery helps to convey these deeper messages and invite reflection from the listener.

lyrics:
Once upon a time
At the foot of a great mountain
There was a town where the people known as happy folk lived
Their very existence a mystery to the rest of the world
Obscured as it was by great clouds
Here they played out their peaceful lives
Innocent of the litany of excessive violence
That was growing in the world below
To live in harmony with the spirit of the mountain called Monkey was enough
Then one day, strange folk arrived in the town
They came in camouflage
Hidden behind dark glasses
And no one noticed them
They only saw shadows
You see
Without the truth of the eyes
The happy folk were blind
summary:
These lyrics seem to tell a story about a peaceful and harmonious community living in isolation from the troubles of the outside world. The mountain called Monkey symbolizes a source of guidance and protection for the town, allowing them to live in peace. However, when outsiders, depicted as "strange folk," arrive and disrupt their way of life, the town is unable to see the danger they pose due to their camouflage and hidden intentions.

The theme of innocence and naivety in the face of outside threats is evident in these lyrics, as the happy folk are unaware of the potential harm these newcomers bring. The importance of seeing the truth and being aware of one's surroundings is emphasized through the metaphor of being blind without the truth of the eyes.

Overall, these lyrics can be interpreted as a cautionary tale about the importance of staying vigilant and not being misled by appearances. It serves as a reminder to remain aware of the intentions of others, especially those who may not have the best interests of the community at heart.

The song portrays the city's contrasting elements, from the glamour of Hollywood to the grittiness of South Central. The references to luxury cars, upscale restaurants, and high-end shopping areas like Mulholland Hill shops and Chanel purse convey a sense of opulence and wealth that is associated with certain parts of LA.

At the same time, the song also highlights the more everyday aspects of life in LA, such as food trucks in East LA, In-N-Out burger, and Denny's. These references speak to the city's melting pot of cultures and the diverse culinary experiences it offers. The lyrics also touch on the social divide between different communities in LA, such as the contrast between Santa Monica helicopters and Compton KJazz, suggesting the economic disparities and cultural differences that exist within the city.

Overall, the song captures the eclectic and dynamic nature of Los Angeles, painting a vivid picture of its beauty, complexity, and contradictions. The repeated mention of KJazz at the end of the song serves as a reminder of the city's rich musical heritage and the role that music plays in shaping its identity.

The mention of previous experiences on labels like B-M-G and C-A-P, but ultimately asserting their independence and control over their own careers, reinforces this idea.

Overall, the lyrics speak to a determination to excel and stand out in their respective fields, while also acknowledging the support and collaborations with others (such as A.L.C and J.O.B). The use of wordplay and metaphors adds depth to the message, emphasizing the importance of creativity and skill in their craft.

The lyrics seem to revolve around themes of materialism, luxury, and flaunting wealth. The artist is expressing their indulgence in expensive items such as Lamborghinis, designer clothing, and jewelry. They talk about only associating with bad or attractive individuals and living a high-end lifestyle. The chorus implies that these material possessions and relationships are what define their existence, with a repeated emphasis on being "outside" to showcase these items and people.

There are also metaphors throughout the lyrics, such as comparing a woman wearing a push-up bra to sucking dick, suggesting a transactional and superficial relationship. The mention of luxury brands like Chrome Hearts, Louis Vuitton, and Benz makes it clear that the artist values status symbols and enjoys the finer things in life. The references to Rolex watches, upscale hotels, and expensive tech further solidify the theme of excess and extravagance. 

Overall, the lyrics present a picture of someone living in a world of opulence and excess, where their worth is tied to their possessions and social status. The repetition of the chorus and the focus on material items suggest a superficial and possibly empty lifestyle that prioritizes wealth and appearance over deeper connections or personal growth.

summary:
The above information provides a detailed overview of Lupe Fiasco's career from 2013 to present, including his music releases, appearances, interviews, awards, and philanthropic efforts. 

In terms of themes and metaphors in Lupe Fiasco's music, he often explores social and political issues, personal struggles, and introspective reflections. His lyrics are known for their intricate wordplay, storytelling, and thought-provoking messages. He frequently addresses topics such as inequality, injustice, and the complexities of life. 

In his music, Lupe Fiasco uses metaphors to convey deeper meanings and create vivid imagery. For example, in the song "Old School Love", featuring Ed Sheeran, he uses the metaphor of "old school love" to symbolize nostalgia, authenticity, and enduring relationships. In "Battle Scars" with Guy Sebastian, he uses the metaphor of wounds and scars to represent emotional pain and struggles. 

Overall, Lupe Fiasco's music is characterized by its lyrical complexity, social commentary, and powerful storytelling, making him a respected and influential artist in the hip-hop genre.

The reference to music as a means of conveying emotions and experiences, as well as the mention of popular culture and materialism in music videos, could reflect a commentary on the current state of the music industry and the pressure to conform to certain standards. summary:
The lyrics of the song "This Is For My Niggas" by Lupe Fiasco touch on themes of struggle, perseverance, and resilience in the face of adversity. The lyrics paint a vivid picture of life in the hood, with references to violence, prison, and political activism. 

The metaphor of being a city slicker and a political prisoner highlights the challenges faced by individuals in urban environments, where survival often requires navigating complex systems of power and oppression. The reference to being a "fast black man author" and a "slower white man warner" speaks to the racial dynamics at play in society, where black individuals are often marginalized and criminalized while white individuals are given more leeway and privilege.

The lyrics also touch on themes of self-expression and defiance, with references to music, sports, and rebellion. The imagery of being thrown out of a basketball game and arguing with the referee symbolize a refusal to conform to societal norms and expectations. The reference to dodging corrections and moving forward without looking back suggests a sense of determination and forward momentum in the face of obstacles.

Overall, the lyrics of the song convey a sense of defiance, resilience, and solidarity among marginalized communities, highlighting the importance of staying true to oneself and standing up against injustice.

The hook, in particular, focuses on the idea of proving oneself through physical actions, like lifting your arms up to show you're ready for a fight. The verses expand on this theme, with Da Pak, Lupe Fiasco, and others boasting about their skills, connections, and willingness to engage in criminal activities.

lyrics:
The Television Will Not Be Revolutionized


Idiot boxes of the world unite! To fight off the effects of intelligence, replace smart quotes with fart jokes, substitute sense with scenes from Martin, let the baby’s bathe in that glow and learn all manner of things they don’t really need to know!


The Television Will Not Be Revolutionized!


Channel the content of some rambling nonsense deep into the annals of yo’ subconscious, deprogram and depress chasing some televised success
Be them, that, they and those be everything but in control


The Television Will Not Be Revolutionized!


Small claims Court drama, teenage baby mamas, Osama watching Osama, Celebrity Endorsed indoor saunas, the perfectly cooked piraña and other cannonfodder for you to ponder, all at the speed of imitations of life
 
while the smoke of war gets inhaled thru the peace pipes
, 
be still my beating heart and scare my brain from thinking thoughts as I sit intoxicated by the delights,
 
sarcasm and 3 strikes thrown by my favorite pitcher in a sound surrounded, 3 dimensional, high death, full color mixture, wholly unsocializing and completely uncensored


The Television Will Not Be Revolutionized!


By this one-eyed monster most of the world was raised
, 
and by this hero most of the world was saved
, 
and to this master most of the world is slaves
, 
it factors your fears with actors and cheers from a live studio audience pushing you to engage in a heroic act of thoughtlessness for the grand prize of a little bread
, 
fleeting fame in the circus and every thought in yo head


The Television Will Not Be Revolutionized!

“
Ain’t no changing me” said my flat screen TV, No More Che’s to the rescue, or Black Panthers to correct you, just coaxial cables and satellite signals to connect you to a world that doesn’t really look like it does on TV
, 
where everything is much shorter, fatter, uglier and in disorder, where u have to do it now because there are no digital recorders where if the present gets boring you can just fast forward


The Television Will Not Be Revolutionized!


So there will be no revolution, or paradoxically ironic televised public execution of the entire worldwide televising institution, there won't even be a celebritized, televised trial of old baby blue, cuz you see my dear friends the television will not be revolutionized but what about the revolution that should taking place inside………………….of you?
summary:
These lyrics seem to be critiquing the role of television in society and its impact on individuals. The use of humor and sarcasm throughout the song suggests a sense of resignation to the idea that television is not going to change or be revolutionized. The lyrics highlight how television can be a tool for distraction, manipulation, and even control, with references to mindless content, consumerism, and the promotion of superficiality.

The metaphor of the "one-eyed monster" representing the television as a powerful force that shapes our thoughts and behaviors is particularly strong. The lyrics also touch on the idea of escapism, highlighting how television can be used as a way to avoid facing the harsh realities of the world.

Overall, the lyrics challenge the listener to consider the impact of television on their own lives and to question whether they are allowing themselves to be passively influenced by what they see on the screen. Ultimately, the song seems to suggest that real change and revolution need to come from within, rather than from external sources like television.

tite: Teriyaki Joe: Neo-Harlem Detective (Chapter Five: Gumbo)
lyrics:
[December 5, 2013:]
Teriyaki Joe: Neo-Harlem Detective

Chapter 5: 
Gumbo


Morning. 
The sky is a television screen.
 
The "sky" is the bottom of Central Park


A sunrise and a sunset and all other galactic phenomenon are broadcasted across the bottom of Central Park to be viewed by us Downstairs


The bottom of Neo-Harlem provides the same courteous service to Neo-Orleans which won its spot underneath us. We call it the basement

Underneath that in no particular order is Old London, Sau Paulo, what's left of Los Angeles & Moscow and that's pretty much it


City states stacked on top of each other like a shish kabob.
 Earth decided to a go a little nuts orbitally speaking.

Scientist still can't explain it. But in short Earth began spinning out of control &. what wasn't literally thrown into space was BBQ'd off.

Some say that's it all a conspiracy and were actually living inside some science project out in the middle of the desert & 
nothing is real.


Either way here we are. The cities or at least the parts that were able survive the tumult & the apocalyptic meltdown that followed...

..signed treaties and created 
"The Caste" with the ruthless & rich Central Park literally at the top and us unlucky bastards at the bottoms.


The rest of the planet is either fully automated manufacturing facilities or nothing. Central Park controls all modes of production.


Everything else, 
religion,
 philosophy, crime, etc just kind gets in where it fits in. Not lawless but definitely "law-least." Why not?

When the very Earth you live on takes an unexpected shit on you & your way of life everything kinda goes out of focus. Welcome to the blur.


The position of the real Sun over Central Park hasn't changed in about 100 years.
 If it wasn't 4 the Nano-Gravy it would've been burned away.

It's literally the tip of the iceberg. Gotta be "born" there to live there kinda jazz. An Invitation only Taichi party for the fancy tyrant.

It's ultra-simplistic in form. Just grass, the glass buildings and the all encompassing Gravy. 
No history, no future. Just never-ending now.


No pressures, no sympathies. Just calm and nihilism. Hence why 11's request, I mean threat, to bring his daughter back is so out of order.

Down here in Neo-Harlem it's none of that. It's all about maximum consumption all the time. Crime & nostalgia & love & hate.

Living like no tomorrow was yesterday. Like the end of the world came and left us behind like bastards on the steps of an abandoned church.

Luckily ppl still want2 find things so that keeps me employed. Luckily 4 them Im really good @ it but maybe not so lucky 4 me this time tho.

I spent the night pondering my next few moves. I knew I needed a Mambo Queen and that meant going Downstairs to Neo- Orleans.

For obvious reasons I'll need a disguise. And a guide who knows her way around...
an Eve to lead Adam to the Apple tree.
 
An Eve indeed!


---End Of Chapter 5---

#TJNHD
summary:
The above text seems to be a part of a dystopian, futuristic narrative where Earth has undergone a catastrophic event and society is now divided into different stacked city states. The top city, Central Park, is described as a place of luxury and control, while the bottom city, Neo-Harlem, is depicted as a place of chaos and crime.

The theme of class division and social hierarchy is evident in the description of how Central Park controls all modes of production and resources, while the lower cities struggle to survive. The metaphor of Central Park being at the top and the other cities being below it symbolizes power and privilege.

The mention of the "Nano-Gravy" and the position of the Sun over Central Park adds a layer of mystery and intrigue to the narrative. The character of Teriyaki Joe seems to be a detective navigating this complex and dangerous world, searching for answers and solutions.

Overall, the text explores themes of power, control, survival, and the blurred lines between reality and illusion. It creates a unique and intriguing setting for the story to unfold.

summary:
The above lyrics from "Teriyaki Joe: Neo-Harlem Detective" Chapter 4 titled "Pie" seem to delve into themes of power, love, deception, and the complexity of human nature. The main character, Teriyaki Joe, seems to be caught in a web of conflicting emotions and choices, as he navigates a dangerous world where money and danger go hand in hand.

The mention of love in the streets and the business of love hints at the idea of relationships being transactional and perhaps superficial in this gritty setting. The reference to the Mohawk and the 10,000 Units suggest a superficial attraction that may not be built on genuine emotions.

The mention of the Taichi and the Parkers alludes to a sense of balance and order in a chaotic world, but also hints at the potential for violence and conflict beneath the surface. The threat of updating every food pill in Neo-Harlem to cause harm to the residents highlights the power dynamics at play and the consequences of greed and corruption.

The discussion of getting rich and saving Neo-Harlem versus getting lost in the VooDoo and potentially destroying the city captures the struggle between good and evil, and the thin line between heroism and villainy. The idea of having a gun to your head and money in your hands symbolizes the choices and temptations that can lead to moral compromises.

Overall, the lyrics in this chapter touch on themes of power, morality, love, and the complexities of human nature in a dark and dangerous urban setting. The metaphor of pie symbolizes the ease of some tasks compared to others, and hints at the unpredictable and challenging nature of life in Neo-Harlem.

Ultimately, the lyrics convey a sense of longing for the days when comedy was a powerful tool for speaking truth to power and sparking important conversations.

tite: Teriyaki Joe: Neo-Harlem Detective (Chapter Six: Dressing)
lyrics:
[December 8, 2013:]

Chapter 6: Dressing


She laughed at me at first. I caught her leaving the diner on her way to work.

She stopped laughing when I showed her the high side of a million Units for her troubles if she so volunteered for the task at hand.


Her body was perfect. Her timing was perfect. Everything had a symmetry. It all fit together with no excess. Seamless. I knew better.

This was all somebody's chess. Lotta thought went into it. Big thinking too. Either I'm underestimating someone or they are me.


Either way I'm on the board now and I feel that the games just getting started. She's gonna know somebody that knows somebody. She did.

She's gonna ask for more money. She does. I'm gonna hard nose. I did. She's gonna say "Well baybee you won't cha Mambo Queen or not?" I did.

She's a real looker. She knows. All part of the plan. 
Beauty & trouble always come together & if the beauty is this big then the trouble...


---Have A Look Inside The Diner Mr. Teriyaki (It's Joe!!)

I look in through the diner window & see people shaking violently & collapsing.

I ask her did she eat anything in there. She says no somewhat startled at the scene taking place back in the diner. I rush in.

The waitresses are motionless, horrified. People grab at their own necks in chaos and last gasps before dropping to the floor lifeless.

---4 Days Mr. Teriyaki...Godspeed---

Son of a bitch. 39 dead. Poisoned. Food Pills. Messy. Poor bastards. Talk about motivation. Shit.


I take Pricele$$ back to my office.
 She's shook. All kinds of shook. She sits down on the couch and manages to steady herself.


I don't tell her how what just happened @ the diner is connected to our little vacation down to Neo-Orleans
 
or that in the light her eyes...


"What you know about sum Rick Ross?" She motions to the antique poster on the wall.
 Small talk to take the mind off the massacre.

I like the old school I tell her. Old fashioned. Old music. Old guns. One foot in and one foot out. She remembers something and smiles.

"I like both feet in the pool baybee." She says while pulling two real cigarettes from her small purse. She walks one over to me.

We have a moment. I dont remember lighting it. She's back on the couch now. Wisps of smoke spiral toward the ceiling. Everything is cool.

Next train 2 Neo-Orleans leaves in an hour. Just enough time 2get a proper disguise. 
A guy could really stick out in a city full of women.


------End of Chapter 6-----
summary:
The above passage seems to depict a tense and dangerous situation, with the protagonist getting involved in a high-stakes game involving a mysterious woman named Pricele$$. The mention of a diner poisoning incident and the connection to a trip to Neo-Orleans suggest a complex and dangerous plot that the protagonist is caught up in.

The themes of beauty, danger, and deception are prevalent throughout the passage, with Pricele$$ being described as beautiful but also potentially treacherous. The use of chess metaphors and references to Rick Ross music suggest a strategic and calculated approach to the unfolding events.

The mention of disguises and the need to blend in further emphasize the idea of deception and the need to navigate carefully in a dangerous environment. Overall, the passage hints at a larger conspiracy or plot that the protagonist is just beginning to unravel, with Pricele$$ and the diner incident being just the tip of the iceberg.

summary:
The lyrics in this verse from Lupe Fiasco touch on a variety of themes and metaphors, showcasing his lyrical prowess and depth of thought. He begins by talking about testing out a new microphone he got from Guitar Center, setting the stage for his verses. He then goes on to mention Ramadan and sends well wishes to those fasting during that time.

In the verse itself, Lupe delves into topics such as the struggles and challenges faced by black individuals living in difficult circumstances, drawing parallels to apartheid-era Soweto. He talks about the complexities of life and the ways in which he seeks to navigate and make sense of it all. He blends in references to pop culture, history, and personal reflection to create a rich tapestry of imagery and ideas.

The metaphor of connecting the dots, like making a pepperoni pizza, speaks to the process of piecing together the various aspects of life and experience to create a coherent whole. He references current events and political figures, adding a layer of social commentary to his lyrics.

Overall, the lyrics in this verse showcase Lupe Fiasco's skill as a wordsmith and his ability to delve deep into complex themes while still maintaining a sense of playfulness and creativity. The imagery and metaphors he uses create a vivid picture of his thought process and perspective on the world around him.

The lyrics in the above passage touch on a variety of themes and use metaphors to convey a sense of introspection, social commentary, and personal struggle. The artist reflects on the complexities of life, expressing a desire to push boundaries and break free from societal constraints.

The lyrics explore themes of self-reflection and introspection, as the artist delves into their own thoughts and feelings. They also touch on societal issues such as violence, poverty, and the struggle for success. The metaphor of a guppy in a net symbolizes feeling trapped or confined, while the comparison to Malcolm X and references to historical figures suggest a sense of empowerment and resistance.

The artist uses vivid metaphors to convey their thoughts and emotions, painting a picture of a world filled with contradictions and challenges. The imagery of slicing fruit like a ninja and flying cars with diamonds in the aim holes evoke a sense of fantasy and ambition, while references to prostitution, drug addiction, and police brutality highlight the harsh realities of life.

Overall, the lyrics in the passage are rich with symbolism and thought-provoking imagery, creating a complex and layered narrative that invites listeners to contemplate the deeper meanings behind the words.

These lyrics are a collaboration between Lupe Fiasco and Nick Javas discussing the intense rivalry between the Chicago Bears and Green Bay Packers in the NFL. The lyrics showcase themes of competition, determination, and the intense passion and pride that fans have for their teams.

The metaphor of players as warriors on the field, battling it out for victory, is prevalent throughout the lyrics. References to iconic players from both teams, like Julius Peppers and Greg Jennings, highlight the skill and talent that is brought to the game. The lyrics also touch on the history and tradition of the rivalry, dating back decades, adding depth and significance to the matchup.

The mention of the Super Bowl ring being "repo'd" emphasizes the high stakes of the game and the importance of winning for both teams. The lyrics capture the excitement and intensity of a football game, building up the anticipation for the ultimate showdown between the Bears and Packers.

Overall, these lyrics evoke the energy and passion of football fans, as well as the dedication and drive of the players on the field. The imagery and metaphors used paint a vivid picture of the rivalry and the emotions that come with it.

lyrics:
Hey Moneyman the crowd is outside. The past, the future and the now is outside.
 The teachers and cooks and the drop-outs too. Word on the street is they looking for you…

Hey Moneyman they saying whats the score? And how much blood have you spilled on the butcher shop floor? Those numbers keep running but what they running into? The crowd is outside and they asking of you…

Hey Moneyman Moneyman the mayors' on the phone. He says he wants to know if all those people went home. Those momma's and poppa's and students and cooks. Those teachers and preachers, one second I'll look…

Hey Moneyman Moneyman the tents are still up, the songs are still singing and the coffee's in cups. The nights due to fall and the sun's going down but its still a whole mess of good folks hanging round...

They eyes are wide and their voices are loud. Its white and black and colorless proud. 
The signs are big and the smiles are bright
. By heaven I reckon its gone be one hell of a night!

Hey Moneyman poor Moneyman you should slip out the back. Cuz the forces of greed are under attack. 
No bombs or bullets or rocks or guns. Just hashtag's and voices at the tops of their lungs!


And Moneyman Moneyman I won't need a ride. But if you need me…

You can find me outside!

By Wasalu "Lupe Fiasco" Jaco
#OccupyWallStreet
summary:
The above lyrics seem to be addressing the figure of "Moneyman" as a symbol of greed and corruption, possibly representing the oppressive forces of capitalism. The song mentions a crowd of diverse individuals outside, including teachers, cooks, drop-outs, and others, all seeking accountability from Moneyman for the blood and harm he has caused. The lyrics also reference the involvement of political figures like the mayor, who may be trying to quell the dissent.

The themes of protest, solidarity, and resistance are strong throughout the song, with the imagery of people singing, drinking coffee, and staying united in their cause. The lyrics suggest that the power of the people lies in their voices and unity, rather than in violence or aggression.

The metaphor of the "Moneyman" being under attack not by traditional weapons but by hashtags and voices highlights the potential for peaceful protest and activism to challenge systems of power. The call to action at the end of the song, urging Moneyman to "slip out the back" and acknowledging that change is coming from the collective voices outside, speaks to the power of grassroots movements and the potential for social change when people come together for a common purpose.

The lyrics above talk about the struggles and challenges faced by many people in different situations and environments. The verses paint a picture of poverty, hardship, and the resilience of individuals fighting to survive and provide for themselves and their families. The mention of living in shelters, trailer parks, or projects, and the lack of basic necessities like water or proper clothing, showcases the harsh reality that many face.

The song highlights the disparities and injustices in society, where some children have bright futures while others struggle to survive. The chorus emphasizes the struggles of those working multiple jobs just to make ends meet, and the sacrifices made for the sake of family and loved ones.

The children singing in the chorus symbolize the voice of the marginalized and oppressed, expressing the challenges they face and the importance of resilience and perseverance. The lyrics also touch on the idea that money cannot buy happiness, and that despite the pain and struggles, it is important to keep living and pushing forward.

Overall, the song conveys a message of empathy, solidarity, and the importance of recognizing and acknowledging the hardships that many face in their daily lives. It encourages listeners to be mindful of the struggles of others and to appreciate the strength and resilience of those who continue to persevere despite their circumstances.

tite: Lupe Fiasco’s Take on Drake v. Meek Mill
lyrics:
The Haunting

A Letter


To rappers from a rapper
...simply write your own rhymes as much as you can if you are able. 
Ghostwriting, or borrowing lines, or taking suggestions from the room has always been in rap and will always be in rap.
 It is nothing to go crazy over or be offended about unless you are someone who postures him or herself on the importance of authenticity and tries to portray that quality to your fans or the public at large. Then we might have a problem. 
Some of the most pivotal moments in rap have been ghostwritten verses.
 This leads to a bigger point. Rapping is not an easy thing to do. It's takes years of work and trial and error to master some of its finer points. Respect from other MC's comes in many formats. Sales, live performances, realness etc but the one thing that is the most important is the raps themselves at least in the eyes of other serious rappers. The phrase "I'm not a rapper" gets thrown around as if it's a badge of honor. And that's fine. If rap is a side hustle for you or just a come up then by all means may the force be with you. But I know a lot of MC's where rap is the first love and the first thing they think about when they wake up and the last thing they think about when they go to sleep. Rappers who pursue the art form with this level of intention may not become rich and famous off selling their raps to a wide audience but that has never been an accepted metric to begin with in terms of quality or level of skill. The vast majority of rappers will never sell 100 records in their lifetimes let alone millions. But that's not the point, the point is that what pursuing the craft gives us in terms of the intangibles is something that record sales or fame could never represent. We achieve a mastery of language and poetics that competes on the highest levels of discourse across the entirety of human history. We express ourselves creatively and attain a sense of liberation and self-esteem via this sacred mode of creation and communication


Modern Radio and the commercial realm of music has injured rap. 
It set up ambiguous rules and systems for success that don't take into consideration the quality and skill of the rappers craft.
 It redefined rap as just being a beat driven hook with some words in between and an entire generation has surrendered to chasing the format instead of chasing the art form. While mastering any format should be the pursuit of any self-respecting rapper including the commercial format it must be kept clear that it is just one of many formats and that you should strive to master all of them. The art form is kept alive and progressive in the activities of the tens of thousands of rappers around the world who are everyday trying to think of that next witty bar. Trying to put that crazy verse together while at work. Trying to find that word that rhymes with catapult so they can finish off that vivid story rap about their childhood. Meek Mill struck a nerve accusing Drake of having a ghostwriter and the entire rap world reacted on all sides of the fence because rap is alive. It's active and it feels. Its rules and traditions are vibrant and responsive. I enjoy both these brothers music and find inspiration and appreciation from both of them. I remember being in Toronto at Goodfoot years ago and it was a stack of CD's on the counter and the guy behind the counter was like "Lupe you gotta take this CD. It's my mans mixtape." I didn't really pay it any mind I took it to the car and looked it over and just kind of set it aside focused on other things. I vividly remember saying "what kind of rap name is Drake?" The rest is history. Once while in Philly I went to do an interview in a shabby and very hood basement studio complex. I peeked into one of the rooms and it was this tall kid with his shirt off bouncing up and down in the booth with an energy that was electric. I gave him my regards. He gave them back. I think I mentioned something about him cutting his dreads. As I left I remember him rapping something about being a boss. The rest is history. At the end of the day, for better or worse, rap is alive even if some of its greatest moments are written by ghosts
summary:
The letter from a rapper addresses the issue of ghostwriting in the rap industry. The rapper emphasizes the importance of authenticity and skill in the craft of rapping, urging fellow rappers to write their own rhymes and master the art form. The letter also criticizes the commercialization of rap music, which has prioritized catchy hooks and beats over lyrical prowess.

One of the major themes in the letter is the idea of true passion and dedication to the art form of rap. The rapper acknowledges that not all rappers will achieve mainstream success, but emphasizes the intrinsic value of mastering language and poetics through rap. This dedication is contrasted with the commercialized version of rap that prioritizes sales and fame over artistic integrity.

The letter also highlights the dynamic and evolving nature of rap as an art form. The rapper acknowledges the controversy surrounding ghostwriting and the impact it has on the authenticity of the music, but ultimately recognizes that rap is a living, breathing entity that is shaped by the contributions of thousands of dedicated artists worldwide.

Overall, the letter serves as a call to arms for rappers to prioritize artistic growth and expression over commercial success, and to uphold the rich traditions and rules of the rap genre. It celebrates the vibrant community of rappers who continue to push the boundaries of the art form and strive for mastery in their craft.

lyrics:
Dear White Supremacy,

First of all you are not really that supreme. 
While throughout history White Supremacy it must be admitted you have achieved some very dominant positions.
 
These positions have been gained mostly through force or some biological agent such as disease that did a lot of the dirty work for you in advance. I mean and anybody can use force on an unarmed populous and anybody can have smallpox
. 
Not judging, just wanted to point out that having a disease that native folks aren't immune to because they've never seen it doesn't make you strategically smart or tactically superior, just kind of sick.
 
And these dominant positions don't really stand up to the test of time that long either.
 There is nothing about you biologically or physically that denotes an innate mode of supremacy. For that matter there is also nothing about you psychologically, philosophically, cognitively, academically, socially, architecturally, culturally or even financially that signifies a higher position above any other group. 
And to be diplomatic there is nothing about you that denotes innate inferiority as well. So what you really are is something in the middle. You are regular. White Regularity is congruent to all other forms of regularity i.e. Black, Brown, Etc etc. But in regularity there is room for differences and this is where White Regularity shines! Each group gets the same essential universals. Dance, food, music, etc. and it must be admitted that the White Regularity take on these universal institutions has been unbelievably impressive and a great addition to the total world culture
. 
I mean spaghetti and meatballs, Romeo & Juliet, Coldplay, The Tuxedo, lighter than air travel are all world class additions to the collective bucket
 but they are no less or more impressive than every other regular groups take on the universals either. 
And if we really wanted to get analytical every invention is built on inspiration from a previously existing invention
 so the claim of "The Supreme 1st" to do something is highly debatable and except for a few exceptions, impossible! All things human aren't born from a supreme overlord solely working in isolation.
Things are created in collaboration and in tandem with other cultures, knowledge structures and movements and more important, People. I mean if those Muslims didn't catalog all that Greek philosophy for research we might not even know who Plato was
. Now whether this collaboration is forced which is seen so much but not exclusively throughout human history does not take away the fact that it is done with the help of somebody else. 
We are supreme as a spectrum of colors in collaboration. One color does not dominate the other nor can it. Sure Steve Jobs was white. But the guy who built the computer was probably Chinese. And the girl who wrote the programs for the computer is probably from Mumbai. And the raw materials that were used to make it where probably first pulled out of the ground by somebody in South Africa.
 And if you take this highly collaborated upon piece of high technology to an indigenous tribe in the jungles of Brazil they'd probably use it as a boat paddle. And we can go on and on down or up the rabbit hole all day long and you'll always find a regular somebody relying on the abilities of a just as regular somebody else that another regular somebody doesn't even care about. White Supremacy is a lie white regularists tell to themselves in hopes that they can get a one way ticket to the top and hope we other colors overhear it. 
Here's the bad news, ain't no top. Here's the good news though, ain't no bottom neither!
 
It's just the regular ole middle where nobody is safe from being influenced by somebody else's extreme regularness.
 Is your swastika flag printed in Mexico? 
Did you know the swastika is officially from Asia and the subcontinent?
 
Did you know black people had slaves in Africa too?
 
Did you know in the world your considered a minority too?
 
I mean you call us niggers and beaners but you gotta ship all your former Native American land backwood sourced ginseng to China to get money to support your meth habit
. Meth that's made with chemicals produced in India. I mean Hitler hated everything about the Jews expect every possession they had. It's funny how the things you hate so much you have to rely on the most for your survival.
And if you wanted to get really ironic and meta about it, White Supremacy has to validate it's on identity based solely on its relationship to other races! I mean now that's what I would call joined at the hip. Without us there is no white supremacy because there would be nothing to supreme over! That sounds so stupid but sometimes the truth is stupid.
 
Stupid like a fox. And no not stupid like a Fox News I mean the real fox. The animal.

In closing white regularity (the race formerly know as white supremacy) I myself on behalf of my own black regularity salute you. Good luck with the northwest front I hear it's beautiful in the spring and probably a strategic death trap if and when 
Yellowstone finally decides to blow up!

Yours Truly

Wasalu "Lupe" Jaco
summary:
The lyrics written by Lupe Fiasco address the concept of White Supremacy and dismantle the notion of superiority based on race. The song challenges the idea that one group is inherently superior to others and highlights the collaborative nature of human achievements throughout history. It emphasizes the interconnectedness of different cultures and peoples, debunking the idea of a hierarchy based on race.

The lyrics also touch on the irony of White Supremacy relying on and being influenced by other races in various aspects of society, such as culture, technology, and economy. They expose the hypocrisy of White Supremacy, as it ultimately relies on the contributions and collaborations of people from different racial backgrounds.

Overall, the song celebrates diversity and unity among all races, rejecting the idea of one group being superior to others. It encourages readers to challenge and question the narrative of White Supremacy and recognize the interconnectedness and contributions of all races to human progress.

The lyrics seem to be a tribute to George Floyd, referred to as "Big Floyd" in the song, who was a victim of police brutality and sparked widespread protests against racial injustice. The chorus emphasizes the beauty and dignity of being black, in a society that often marginalizes and discriminates against black individuals. 

The verse reflects on George Floyd's life and legacy, highlighting his love for his community, his activism, and the impact of his final words. The mention of "every twenty dollar bills" alludes to the counterfeit bill that led to the encounter with the police that resulted in Floyd's death. The lyrics also touch on themes of resilience, unity, and the need for self-love and acceptance within the black community.

The outro is a reflection on staying true to oneself, embracing one's identity, and finding strength in faith and community. It encourages listeners to prioritize their mental health and well-being, rather than comparing themselves to others on social media. Overall, the lyrics convey a message of empowerment, self-worth, and solidarity in the face of adversity.

lyrics:
[Spoken Interlude: Virgil Abloh]
Have you ever asked yourself where the world is inside the solar system?
Like, where are we?
Like, where does the planet sit amongst all the stars?
Who knows, it's a super brain freeze
But an easier question than that is to ask yourself
Where we sit in the sea of art history
Like, that's tangible, that's man-made
Man-made art, so the history of it, we fit in
Another like, sort of framework to dwell on is, like, where do we live?
You know, you live in a house
I guarantee the house that you grew up in is what you define as a house
But, for someone that grew up on the opposite side of the world
What they grew up in, they think of as a house
A kitchen, a living room, a roof, a door, etcetera
Just shit to think about, you know
Whole bullet point is, the world inside it is man-made
It's all metaphoric, man has flaws
Man loves power, everything is man-made
And, what's more dangerous than that?
But, as I digress
summary:
The spoken interlude by Virgil Abloh raises questions about our place in the world and in art history. He prompts listeners to consider where we sit in the solar system and among the stars, but also where we sit in the sea of art history. This poses the idea that man-made constructs and history play a significant role in defining our existence and understanding of the world.

Abloh also explores the concept of homes and how our perception of what constitutes a house is shaped by our own experiences and upbringing. This idea challenges the notion of a universal truth or standard, highlighting the subjective nature of our understanding of the world.

Moreover, the interlude delves into the idea that the world is man-made, filled with flaws and power dynamics. It provokes reflection on the dangers inherent in systems and structures constructed by humans, suggesting that these constructs can be both powerful and potentially harmful.

Overall, the lyrics evoke a sense of introspection and contemplation about our place in the world, the impact of human influence, and the complexities of human-made systems and history.

summary:
The lyrics in this interlude touch on the theme of feeling like an outsider or being bullied for not fitting in with societal norms. The speaker describes being made fun of for being a nerd, with people laughing at their clothes and hair. This can be a metaphor for feeling different or not accepted by others.

The declaration of seeking revenge can be seen as a metaphor for standing up to bullies or overcoming challenges. The speaker expresses their frustration and determination to prove themselves and turn the tables on those who have mistreated them. This theme of empowerment and resilience is a common motif in many narratives, where the underdog triumphs against adversity.

The reference to Lupe Fiasco, a Chicago-based rapper, adds a layer of authenticity and connection to the real world. Lupe's own background and experiences growing up in Chicago's westside may have also shaped his music and lyrics, making him a relatable figure for listeners who have faced similar struggles.

Overall, the interlude captures the emotions and struggles of those who don't fit in with mainstream society and the desire to rise above it. It speaks to the universal experience of feeling like an outsider and finding strength in one's own identity.

These lyrics from Lupe Fiasco's song "Enemy of the State" convey a sense of appreciation and gratitude towards his fans. By describing his relationship with his fans as a love story, he is emphasizing the strong connection and loyalty they have towards each other. The use of the term "enemy of the state" suggests that he may feel like an outsider or rebel within the music industry, but finds solace in the love and support he receives from his fans.

The themes of love, loyalty, and connection are prevalent in these lyrics, highlighting the deep bond that can exist between an artist and their audience. The metaphor of a love story also speaks to the emotional and personal nature of music, as it often serves as a form of self-expression and connection for both the artist and the listener.

Overall, these lyrics suggest that Lupe Fiasco values and appreciates the love and support he receives from his fans, viewing it as a meaningful and important aspect of his career and personal life.

The artist reflects on their journey from starting out at seventeen to facing challenges like getting robbed on their first deal and dealing with label interference. Despite these setbacks, the artist continues to push forward, showcasing their lyrical prowess and dedication to their craft. They also express love and loyalty to their friends and family, particularly mentioning a friend who encouraged them to keep going even when things were tough. The lyrics also convey a sense of defiance and determination in the face of adversity, as the artist refuses to let setbacks hold them back. The mention of signing to different labels and the struggles faced in the music industry serve as metaphors for the broader theme of resilience and perseverance in the face of challenges. Overall, the lyrics convey a message of staying true to oneself and continuing to pursue one's passion despite obstacles.

lyrics:

The topic is the painting used for the T&Y cover

Alright let's get this started the final session of #PhilosophySunday is LIVE!
You know da rules tag ya responses wit #PS or be overlooked

Before we get started I want to say thank you to everybody who has supported #PhilosophySunday over the years!

It was started to use Twitter for some a little more profound and engaging and I think we can say we've been successful!

#PhilosophySunday would not have been possible without fans and arm chair intellectuals chiming in on the topics and striking #TwitterGold!

I want to send a very special thank you  to @wirelessphi for giving #PhilosophySunday a little more philosophical credibility!

Hopefully you guys and gals can continue #PhilosophySunday with @wirelessphi or on your own with your own personal Twitter accounts.

Lastly I want to say sorry to all you football fans who had to make the "tough" lol decision 2 choose between #PS or those Sunday games! Lol

So let's get this started. I (as Wasalu Jaco) started painting a couple years back kinda as a hobby & then got a little more serious
#PS

I found out that the painting became just as meaningful as my music in terms of what idea I was trying to express. Layers of meaning. #PS

Story of how one of my paintings became the cover for 1 of my albums I will save for the memoirs but the painting itself we can discuss #PS

Let's have a look at the painting and the cover #PS
The name of the painting is in Italian "Uomo Mangiato Tigre" and ROUGHLY translates as "Man Eating Tiger" #PS

So let's start there. What is your interpretation of the title "Man Eating Tiger"?
Remember to tag responses with #PS

summary:
The above discussion of Lupe Fiasco's painting "Uomo Mangiato Tigre" delves into the complexities of the human experience and the struggle between man and society, instinct and technology, and the constant battle for survival and identity. The title itself, "Man Eating Tiger," prompts reflection on power dynamics, consumption, control, and the dual nature of humanity.

Themes of duality, resilience, adaptation, and the eternal quest for self-understanding are prevalent throughout the interpretations provided by participants in the discussion. The painting itself, with its imagery of a man and a tiger intertwined, symbolizes the internal and external conflicts that individuals face in navigating their relationships with others and the world around them.

The incorporation of technology in the artwork adds another layer of complexity, highlighting the impact of modern advancements on human behavior and society. The discussion also touches on the dangers of over-dependence on technology and the potential loss of humanity in the pursuit of progress.

Overall, the interpretations of "Uomo Mangiato Tigre" bring to light the interconnectedness of human nature, society, and technology, urging reflection on the constant evolution and challenges of the human experience. The artwork serves as a visual representation of the multifaceted nature of existence and the ongoing quest for balance and meaning in a complex world.

summary:
The above lyrics seem to touch on themes of success, wealth, fame, and the struggles and consequences that come with it. The artist, Lupe Fiasco, talks about his success and how he has worked hard for it, but also acknowledges the pressures and expectations that come with it. He mentions staying true to himself and not conforming to the expectations of others. 

There are also metaphors and references throughout the lyrics, such as comparing his skills to that of a professor or a teller, referencing specific artists and figures in the music industry, and using imagery related to cars, money, and power. Overall, the lyrics seem to convey a sense of confidence and assertiveness, while also addressing social issues and personal reflections.

summary:
The above lyrics illustrate a feud between Letty and Kid Cudi, with Letty expressing her disdain for him and feeling justified in her negative feelings towards him due to his disrespectful actions and behavior. Letty believes that Kid Cudi's actions warrant criticism and confrontation, especially during his time in rehab, where he should be focusing on self-improvement and addressing his own issues.

Zoe, on the other hand, tries to encourage Letty to take the high road and not engage in public beef online. Zoe believes that Letty should rise above the drama and not stoop to Kid Cudi's level by engaging in social media conflicts. Letty, however, remains firm in her belief that Kid Cudi deserves to be called out for his behavior and that she is justified in expressing her frustrations publicly.

The lyrics touch on themes of conflict, public perception, loyalty, and integrity. Letty is portrayed as standing her ground and not being afraid to confront someone who has wronged her, even if it means facing backlash or criticism from others. The lyrics also show the power dynamics of public feuds and the importance of standing up for oneself in the face of adversity. The metaphor of "bringing beef to the Internet" highlights the escalating nature of conflicts in the digital age and the impact of social media on personal relationships and public image.

summary:
The lyrics reflect on the artist's growth and success over the years, acknowledging the support of fans and the impact of his music on the world. The reference to suicide doors and luxury cars symbolizes a sense of escape and luxury, while the mention of political issues and conscious vs commercial music highlights the artist's commitment to addressing important social issues in his work.

The lyrics also pay tribute to influential figures like Nate Dogg and Japan, showing respect for those who have had an impact on the artist's life and career. The mention of DJ's and online platforms like Twitter and blogs highlights the artist's appreciation for the support of the music community and the role of technology in sharing his music.

Overall, the lyrics convey a sense of gratitude, perseverance, and social consciousness, showcasing the artist's growth and dedication to his craft.

summary:
The lyrics in this song seem to touch on themes of self-reflection, struggle, and redemption. The artist seems to be questioning the concept of glory and success, suggesting that sacrificing morals and values to achieve a certain level of success may not lead to true fulfillment. The metaphor of being "trapped in the category" could symbolize feeling confined or limited by societal expectations or norms.

The mention of "glory" and being number 5 in the 40 could represent the idea of striving for recognition and success, but ultimately feeling unfulfilled or incomplete. The reference to "shattered if you dapper poorly" could suggest that putting on a facade or pretending to be something you're not can lead to inner turmoil.

There is also a sense of introspection and accountability in the lyrics, with lines like "love to judge misunderstandings" and "good as galop jamming to a Pakistani." The artist seems to be grappling with personal growth and self-improvement, acknowledging their own mistakes and flaws.

The outro with Ron Isley adds a layer of reflection and longing for change. The lines about washing hands, saying grace, and turning the page suggest a desire to move forward and make amends for past actions. Overall, the lyrics convey a complex mix of emotions and thoughts, exploring themes of identity, redemption, and the struggle for self-improvement.

tite: Lupe Fiasco Named Musical Director of World Cup Team
lyrics:
U.S. Soccer has named Grammy Award-winning recording artist Lupe Fiasco as the Music Director for the Men’s National Team and artist Futura the Art Director for the Men’s National Team’s 2014 FIFA World Cup campaign.

Building on the 
“One Nation. One Team.”
 theme, Chicago-born and Grammy-winning hip-hop artist Fiasco will collaborate with U.S. Soccer in a variety of areas during the Send-Off Series and the World Cup. He will be creating Spotify playlists, in collaboration with his DJ group the SNDCLSH, and handle in-game music programming during the Send-Off Series.

U.S. Soccer is working to promote 
Fiasco’s new single, “Mission,”
 during the Send-Off Series. The single, which is about the fight against cancer, was released on Monday. Fiasco will appear in Times Square in New York during Fan Appreciation Day on May 30, and he will hold a music set in Chicago at the U.S. Soccer Fan Fest prior to the USA’s match against Ghana on June 16.


New York native Futura
, world renowned for his pioneering role in the birth of graffiti-style artwork and designs, will provide his own flavor that will include the official Men’s National Team World Cup poster, limited-edition skate deck designs and other limited-edition items. Futura’s signature style will be tied to the team during the U.S. MNT’s road to Brazil, and he will create two “live” works at the Fan Appreciation Day on May 30 and the U.S. Soccer Fan Fest in Chicago on June 16. Those live works will be auctioned off, with the proceeds benefiting Fiasco’s “Mission” campaign.

Lupe Fiasco, born Wasalu Muhammad Jaco, is a 32-year-old Grammy Award-winning hip hop artist who was once named GQ Magazine’s “Man of the Year” and Rolling Stone Magazine’s “Artist to Watch.” 
Since his breakout hit “Kick Push” in 2006, Fiasco has been praised for his philosophical, sharp and dynamic lyricism.
 His catalogue of albums, 
Food & Liquor, The Cool, LASERS, and Food & Liquor II: The Great American Rap Album Part 1,
 have all received wide critical and commercial success, earning the Chicago-born artist 12 Grammy nominations, numerous RIAA certifications and a No. 1 Billboard Top 200 album.


Fiasco’s fifth studio album, Tetsuo & Youth, is set for release later this year.


Futura, originally known as Futura 2000, is an acclaimed painter, graphic designer, graffiti artist and sports aficionado. He has been a global icon of artistic collaboration for more than 30 years. One of his earliest cross-genre projects included painting live, on-stage murals for the British rock band The Clash. He has since expanded his collaborative horizons, working with apparel designers such as agnès b, Burton and Nike. He has also served, most recently, as theCreative Director for both (RED)’s 2014 global “Dance Red Save Lives” campaign and Sprite’s 2014 NBA All-Star Game art initiative with LeBron James.

Born Leonard McGurr in 1955 in New York, Futura birthed his iconoclastic persona in the streets, and subway tunnels of New York City. He was a friend and contemporary of the legendary Keith Haring. Futura’s abstract art and aerosol strokes have become a staple in public art collections in New York, France,Japan, Hong Kong and Italy. Futura’s artwork and designs have also expanded into additional commercial commissions for the likes of Hennessy/LVMH, A Bathing Ape, Uniqlo, Descente and Levis, to name a few.
summary:
The lyrics in the above text talk about U.S. Soccer's collaboration with Grammy-winning artist Lupe Fiasco and renowned artist Futura for the Men's National Team's 2014 FIFA World Cup campaign. The theme of "One Nation. One Team." emphasizes unity and patriotism, highlighting the team's journey to the World Cup in Brazil. 

Lupe Fiasco's involvement as Music Director involves creating playlists and in-game music programming, as well as promoting his new single "Mission" which focuses on the fight against cancer. Futura, as Art Director, will contribute his distinctive style to the team's official World Cup poster and limited-edition items, with proceeds benefiting Fiasco's "Mission" campaign.

The lyrics also delve into the backgrounds and accomplishments of both artists. Lupe Fiasco's musical career and critical acclaim are highlighted, along with Futura's pioneering role in graffiti-style artwork and collaborations with various brands.

Themes of collaboration, creativity, and philanthropy resonate throughout the text, showcasing how music and art can come together to support a common cause and uplift a team and its fans. The metaphor of artists bringing their unique talents to the soccer world reflects the fusion of different creative disciplines in a shared goal of success and unity.

The lyrics seem to be a detailed and passionate review of Jay-Z's album "4:44". The writer expresses their admiration for Jay-Z's lyrical prowess and storytelling ability, as well as their appreciation for the production of the album. The metaphors used, such as comparing the beats to Sanaa Lathan's hair or the artistry separating the "bullshit from the Bulls Chips", convey the writer's deep connection and understanding of the music. 

Themes of introspection, vulnerability, and growth seem to be prevalent throughout the review. The writer mentions how the album made them reflect on their own relationships and behavior, as well as the impact of Jay-Z's personal revelations on the listener. The review also touches on the evolution of Jay-Z's artistry and the duality of his persona, from the more mainstream-friendly "Tribeca Jay" to the raw and gritty "Brooklyn Jay".

Overall, the review praises "4:44" as a masterpiece and gives it a perfect rating of 10/10. It highlights the album's enduring quality and its ability to resonate with listeners on a deep and emotional level.

They also challenge the normative narratives of African American history and envision a future where equality and success are attainable for all.

The metaphor of "all black everything" is used to symbolize a world where African Americans are celebrated and revered, where black culture is prominent and influential. It serves as a powerful image of empowerment and pride.

He reflects on the concept of staying true to oneself and not allowing external pressures to dictate one's actions or beliefs. The reference to wearing a sweater in summer symbolizes the idea of perseverance and resilience in the face of adversity.

The references to luxury brands and high-end items like Visvim moccasins and Cartier watches serve as metaphors for success and status, but Lupe also emphasizes the importance of staying grounded and not getting caught up in materialism. The line about limited edition items like vintage shoes and episodes of Dennis the Menace highlights the uniqueness and individuality that comes with staying true to oneself.

Overall, these lyrics convey a message of authenticity, resilience, and self-awareness in the face of societal pressures and expectations. Lupe Fiasco encourages listeners to stay true to themselves and not get swept up in superficiality, but to instead focus on personal growth and staying true to one's own values.

The lyrics are reflecting on the artist's journey in the rap industry over the past six years. They talk about the artist's rise to fame, their dedication to their craft, and their commitment to staying true to themselves. The lyrics also mention the struggles and challenges the artist has faced, both personally and professionally.

Themes in the lyrics include perseverance, honesty, self-expression, and the artist's relationship with their fans. The metaphor of "the gift" represents the artist's talent and creativity, while "the curse" may refer to the challenges and pressures of being in the spotlight.

Overall, the lyrics convey a sense of determination and resilience in the face of obstacles, as well as a desire to continue to grow and evolve as an artist.

The metaphor of finding diamonds in a sandwich and luxury items in everyday food items could symbolize finding unexpected value or beauty in ordinary things, reflecting the artist's ability to elevate and transform the mundane into something special. Additionally, the mention of serving "pearls from socio-political menus" suggests that the artist is using their platform to address important social issues and deliver meaningful messages through their music.

Overall, these lyrics seem to celebrate personal growth, self-acceptance, and the ability to turn challenges into opportunities. There is a sense of defiance and resilience in the face of criticism, with the artist embracing their own uniqueness and success.

Overall, the lyrics convey a sense of confidence and fearlessness, as the artist navigates through challenging situations with ease and skill. The theme of perseverance and resilience shines through as the artist triumphantly emerges from seemingly impossible scenarios.

summary:
The lyrics of the song "The Show Goes On" by Lupe Fiasco convey a message of resilience, perseverance, and determination in the face of adversity. The rapper talks about the challenges and struggles faced by people in different situations, from feeling like they are being taken advantage of to dealing with difficult circumstances in ghettos and impoverished areas.

Throughout the song, Lupe Fiasco encourages listeners to keep pushing forward and not let obstacles hold them back. He emphasizes the importance of staying true to oneself, standing up for what is right, and never giving up despite the hardships encountered.

The repeated chorus of "The show goes on" serves as a reminder to keep moving forward, to continue dreaming and striving for a better future, even when faced with setbacks or difficulties. The lyrics also touch on themes of hope, empowerment, and solidarity, urging individuals to uplift each other and support one another in times of need.

Overall, the song's message is one of resilience, empowerment, and the belief that no matter what challenges may arise, the show must go on, symbolizing the perseverance and determination needed to overcome obstacles and achieve success.

The mention of older gaming consoles like Nintendo, Genesis, and TurboGrafx, as well as arcade cabinets, invoke feelings of fond memories and simpler times. The references to cheat codes, secret treasures, and final bosses speak to the thrill and challenge of gaming.

Metaphorically, the lyrics compare playing video games to various aspects of life. The idea of knowing when to run, jump, or slide can be seen as a reflection of decision-making and strategy in real life. The mention of saving at the right part and reaching the next checkpoint imply resilience and perseverance in the face of challenges.

Overall, the song celebrates the escapism and fun that video games provide, while also highlighting the importance of nostalgia, memory, and the joy of immersing oneself in a virtual world. It captures the essence of the gaming culture and the sense of community that comes with it.

summary:
These lyrics seem to touch on themes of resistance against societal norms and systems of oppression. The reference to "divide and conquer" suggests a recognition of the manipulative tactics used by those in power to maintain control. The mention of consumerism and the pressure to constantly strive for bigger and better things speaks to the idea of capitalism and how it can lead to self-destructive behavior.

The metaphor of a "healthy tree" with a sick seed symbolizes the idea that even if outward appearances may seem successful or grand, if the foundation is flawed or corrupted, it will eventually collapse. The reference to historical figures like James Baldwin, Noam Chomsky, and Cornell West suggests a respect for intellectual voices that challenge the status quo and advocate for justice.

The line "the only thing I fear is ham on this here sandwich" may be a humorous way of expressing a refusal to conform to societal expectations or fears, highlighting a sense of independence and self-assurance. Overall, these lyrics convey a sense of defiance and a commitment to staying true to one's beliefs despite the potential consequences.

These lyrics are a homage to the iconic comedian and civil rights activist Dick Gregory. The song highlights his life story, from his humble beginnings in St. Louis to his rise in the comedy scene and his impactful activism during the civil rights movement. The lyrics touch on themes of resilience, political activism, social justice, and the power of comedy as a tool for change.

The metaphor of using a microphone as a weapon symbolizes Gregory's ability to use his platform to speak out against injustice and advocate for change. The reference to his advocacy for nutrition and fasting reflects his holistic approach to health and well-being, as well as his commitment to living his values.

The lyrics also emphasize Gregory's enduring legacy and the importance of remembering his contributions to society. The artist, Lupe Fiasco, pays tribute to Gregory's impact on him and encourages listeners to learn more about his life and work. Overall, the lyrics celebrate Gregory as a legendary figure who used his voice and platform to make a difference in the world.

Metaphors like "facial hair started to grow, started a fro" and "make a change like March of The Dimes" suggest a physical and personal transformation, as well as a desire to break away from negative influences and make positive changes in their life. Overall, the lyrics convey a sense of perseverance, resilience, and the importance of self-reflection and growth.
