tite: Meditations On A New Diasporic Mythology Complex
lyrics:
I think as we begin to think about myth, mythology, and the need of mythology - I was basically raised on mythology, introduced to mythology at a very young age. 
Mostly Greek mythology, and of course of that Roman mythology, which kinda took over what the Greeks left off, and kinda super-imposed themselves on a lotta the Greek myths - very directly  in the form of Hercules, and the -cules.
 And that was the kind of literature I was reading as an adolescent, which became my first kind of education into creation of stories, creation of myths, and it was the role of myth being used to establish certain principles and certain narratives and certain answering of questions why in a very fantastic manner and a very supernatural manner, in that sense. But in some capacities, even a very natural manner.

And so, once you're steeped into kinda that education; that formation; you start to think in those capacities, you start to develop your world views and your outlooks based on those kind of templates, those creation templates. As you think of, you know, that's one aspect, and you start to think of those conscious aspects consciously being attended to, and researching, and being entertained by certain narratives, mythical narrates from a certain period. And then you think of the unconscious narratives, and even you think of modern narratives, which are kind of fast-forwarded through time and the narratives which you are introduced to consciously of a more modern kind of piece: the mythology of America, the mythology of globalization, the mythology of - you know, as it stands. A myth kind of being steeped into a certain misunderstanding, and then trying to achieve the understanding reconcile of your ignorance to a certain degree through this template, this mythical template, which lays everything plain and gives you the A plus B equals C and you go on and live your life, all things are well.

But say you think of the modern mythologies, the mythology of the cowboy, the mythology of the gangsta, the mythology of just these supernatural beings - maybe not as supernatural as Zeus, of course, or Hercules, of course - but still bearing the same, some of the same fascinations with the fantastic. And these great abilities and these grand possessions and levels of influence and power, which are steeps, and the ability to influence specifically, the ability to influence discourse, the ability to influence progressions of ideas, the ability to influence women into the bed, the ability to gather large, vast quantities of material possessions, and not only have them, but to have a disdain for them; to be so above it all, once you have it where these things, where there's a certain aesthetic nature to it, that when you've consumed all of these things and at the same time you have the power to relinquish them, to show that they have no value and the way that you treat to them.

And it's very interesting to classify that as mythology, if you know not of it, if you can't see it first-hand, if you don't really have your own creation-kind-of story as to why things are a certain revealed - it has been revealed to you that this is the way it works, these are the mechanics to this particular situation - you're gonna, in my capacity, you're gonna develop it and through myth, through your interaction with myth, through your self-creation of myth.

And so there's a role of mythology. And I think persuing that role and taking on the role of the author of mythology. Even in the circumstance that what you are, this modern, this real -  let's call it this reality, to, you know, translate it into mythology, to regress it back into mythological kind of structure, it opens up new terrain, it opens up new frontiers for expedition: for literary expedition, for critical expedition, for poetic expedition, and from political expedition, from social expedition; and even from a historical expedition, because the nature of mythology is that it is steeped in a misunderstanding - and that misunderstanding never really becomes reconciled. It still exists, this mythology, post-misunderstanding, is really an attempt, a version, one vein in an attempt to explain or to reconcile this misunderstanding. But in it, it in itself is not a reconciliation. Reconciliation is still needed at the base, and that's why we have things like science, and different things which act upon it with all of its philosophies and its experiments and theories to try to achieve the reconciliation of the primary misunderstandings about things. Well, no matter what they are: naturals, the perceived supernaturals, the subnatural, et cetera et cetera...

But there's license. There's license to do as you will, to do as you see fit, to do that, to retain the authorial dimension of saying, "I am going to author mythology, the new mythology - and in this particular instance, the mythology of the diaspora - so, diasporian mythology." Within a modern context looking backwards towards history and not in the attempt, which I think is a new way of looking at it, not in an attempt to reconcile the totality of society to this point, but more to - or I guess that is the question. What is it? Because the attempt isn't to reconcile, I mean you're not trying to reconcile a misunderstanding of what you tryin' to do. Are you just trying to promote? Or are you just trying to point attention towards the misunderstanding? But even within this, there is a reality: It's not just mythology, it is an understanding, and that might be it. It's not that it's a misunderstanding which gives birth to myth. It is a understanding, it is already reconciled, it is already consolidated, it is already real. And but from that reality it births mythology, which kinda turns things on our heads a bit, I think. Alright. DROGAS.
summary:
The above passage delves into the importance and role of mythology in shaping individual and collective consciousness. The speaker discusses how they were introduced to mythology at a young age and how it influenced their understanding of storytelling, creation, and the establishment of principles and narratives. They explore how mythology can be used to answer questions in a fantastic and supernatural manner, while also addressing modern mythologies like the cowboy or gangsta.

One of the major themes in the passage is the idea of mythology as a way to reconcile misunderstandings or to create new narratives that give meaning to existence. The speaker discusses the role of the author in creating mythology and the potential for myth to be a tool for literary, critical, political, and social exploration.

The speaker also touches on the concept of diasporian mythology, suggesting a new way of looking at myth within the context of historical and cultural displacement. They question whether the purpose of creating new myths is to promote understanding, point out misunderstandings, or simply to draw attention to the complexities of reality.

Overall, the passage explores the dual nature of mythology as both a reflection of reality and a means of transcending it through storytelling and imagination. It encourages readers to think critically about the myths that shape their worldview and to consider the power of creating new narratives to navigate the complexities of existence.

The lyrics seem to be commenting on the cycle of consumerism, technology, and societal norms in modern society. The artist discusses the obsession with new products, such as the latest iPhone, and how it can lead to a sense of superficiality and emptiness. The reference to standing in line for new products symbolizes the constant desire for the next new thing and the pressure to keep up with trends.

The lyrics also touch on themes of spirituality and existentialism, questioning the purpose of life and whether material possessions can truly bring fulfillment. The references to God, acceptance of cash, and atheism suggest a struggle with belief and a search for meaning in a world focused on materialism.

The metaphor of the vessel in the bloodline and the thirteenth zodiac sign could be interpreted as a reflection on the cyclical nature of life and the idea that everything is interconnected. The references to winter battles and summer children being born further emphasize this idea of cycles and continuity.

Overall, the lyrics seem to convey a sense of disillusionment with society's focus on consumerism and technology, and a longing for deeper meaning and connection.

lyrics:
A Letter

The police are not your friend. The police are not your enemy. The same could be said about the law. So let's say it. The law is not your friend and the law is not your enemy. So what are the police then if they are not friends nor enemies. Well let's get a definition of the word 'Police' from the dictionary: "the civil force of a national or local government, responsible for the prevention and detection of crime and the maintenance of public order." And while we're at it lets get a dictionary definition of 'Law' as well: "the system of rules that a particular country or community recognizes as regulating the actions of its members and may enforce by the imposition of penalties." Nowhere in the definition does it say "friend" or "enemy" even though some police officers can be friendly and some can be really antagonistic (see the famed "Good Cop/Bad Cop" routine for an explicit example) it is not the nature of their position in society to be friend or foe. So what are the police then? The firmest designation for the police is their primary title "Law Enforcement Officer" and again the law is neither your friend or foe so then the police are a merely reflection of the law. Police are the physical manifestation of the law. The police occupy a middle ground of sorts. They are mostly benign in the sense that if they have no particular law to enforce then they are powerless. Also where the law is broken and can't be seen or is out of the conscious knowledge of the police they are also powerless as is the law itself. Law is only powerful when it comes into direct contact with its child, Criminality. Crime and our relationship to crime is much closer to us than our relationship to the law. Everybody bends or breaks the law in some very minute capacity. We may speed on the highway from time to time. Throw litter on the ground. Lie on our taxes. Disregard a jury duty summons. Download pirated content. Where we feel the law doesn't "count" or "make sense" we are inclined to transgress the limits. Furthermore Crime is celebrated in all annals of entertainment and culture. In movies and books and song and TV. When was the last time you heard a song on the radio about the fabulous and sexy lifestyles of being a cop? In movies and TV it is much different as police officers are portrayed as being heroic figures but how many times within those same films or TV shows a police officer goes "outside" the law to rectify some injustice or solve some crime. How many movie cops had to "give up their badge" to the captain because they broke the rules to catch the bad guy? In effect they had to become criminals to enforce to the law. Think of Batman. Commissioner Gordon uses him when things get a little too out of hand in Gotham City and he needs somebody who isn't bound to the letter of the law and all that that entails to deal with the villainous hordes. This maybe "fictional" but then again is it really? How many real life cops put guns and drugs on people to get an arrest possibly on people who they know for a fact are committing serious crimes but can't prove it? How many cops "invent" a probable cause to effect a search of someone's property and eventually "find what they were looking for" even though what they found was not the initial reason they stopped the person? How many cops beat confessions out of people? How many cops flat out lie when it comes to what they saw or did during arrests and follow up investigations? How many cops have used terroristic threats to get people to comply to testifying or admitting to things they didn't commit? How many cops work for the same criminals they are employed to pursue in the forms of bribes and information? But then how many citizens do the same exact things? "Police Officer" and "Law Enforcement Officer" are just titles, roles, positions, names. No different than "typewriter" or "car." What gives these things life are the people that use them. Some people just do not know how to type or drive and it must be said that some people just don't know how to be police officers in strict accordance with the law. One problem is that becoming a police officer or law enforcement officer is a very structured and ordered bureaucratic process. It is very rigid and rather systematic. It is literally uniformed to stand as the visible and physical counterpoint to the non-uniformed wildness that is on the one smaller end, society itself and on the other larger end, criminality. Crime is subtle and blends well into the wild variety of society. Crime is successful because it is asymmetric and forever evolving. It can go unnoticed. Hence why the most successful police operations are done "undercover" and the most visible criminal activities are the least successful. The ability to blend into the "wildness" of society and mimic it is the best tactic for success outside of pure anarchy. Crime is highly adaptable. It is highly revered because its heroes have excellent leadership qualities and in some cases very deep philanthropic sentiments. Crime is the true equal opportunity employer and is one of the only organizations to successfully overcome the racial divides. Criminals are the embodiment of the material American Dream. Freedom (even from taxation!), upward mobility and the pursuit of happiness. All crimes have victims but one could say quite successfully that all things have victims. In the business world, victims are classified under the term externalities. For example, some people call perfectly legal mountain top removal coal mining a crime against humanity as it has the potential to build up then completely destroy entire communities not to mention the sometimes irreversible environmental externalities. Laws sometimes have a weird way of creating their own criminal enemies, hence the "child" term used earlier. Take for instance prohibition, it was a perfectly sound moral concept to combat what was seen by some as the scourge of drunkenness and all its hideous social and moral externalities, just imagine drunk driving back in the 20's! This perfectly sound moral law however single handedly created the mafia, the worlds greatest and most successful organized criminal enterprise. The emergence of the mafia lead to the creation of the FBI which was needed to be a "higher" form of law enforcement to combat the mob. The FBI tactics included all sorts of law bending and law creation to try and successfully tackle the problem the same government that employed them unwittingly created in the first place. The cultural impact of the mafia was instantaneous and deep even up to this day. For example, we all know off top who Al Capone was but would struggle to find out who the president of the United States was during the time Al Capone was alive. And without Google today I'd say some of us would probably never know or even care to find out. The legal limits were stretched to the fight the mafia then and they are still being stretched to this day to justify your parking ticket or your "failure to signal." So what does all this mean? Is it right? Is it wrong? Is it fair? Is there a solution? Unfortunately and fortunately there is no one solution. Law enforcement and criminality are like hand and glove. They are forever connected and as long as you have one you'll have the other and all the externalities from both sides that come along with them. Abuse of authority by authority will be balanced somewhere on the other side by abuse of the system by criminality. Freddy Grey dies unjustly in police custody on one side and El Chapo escapes from prison on the other side. An eye for and eye to be biblical about it. One hard solution to swallow for many is to just obey the law. Buuuuuut this "simple" solution also can create a set of dubious illegitimate children of its own because the law inextricably represents much more than its face value of "do not do and you will not be punished" for some "obey" is equated to "starve" or "go without" or "be poor" or "be insulted" or "be bored" or "be trapped in a vicious circle of economic and academically induced depression simply because I lost the biological lottery of life and was born into a family of second or third class citizens at a time and place where social status is dictated by race which also dictates access to the apparatuses of upward mobility etc etc etc..." Sometimes "obey" explicitly means die. This is the root of the plague of vendetta that is sweeping through Chicago. The ever viral and ever rational and true "Kill Or Be Killed" mentality. For some "obey" MEANS "punishment." This misunderstanding of metaphorical process when it comes to how we refer, frame and live through the narratives of our individual lives is what causes much of the conflict. Objective law has little wiggle room for subjective reality. What "law enforcement officer" means in a dictionary and the courts can be far from the definition that it has on the streets and in practice. Police officers can be defined on the streets as surely protecting and serving but protecting and serving the wills of a corrupt authoritative system that if allowed to have its way will mean poverty forever and access denied ad infinitum. Police officers must be trained to assess not only the dangers of a situation but also the desperation of a situation. Is it just a coincidence that a synonym for criminal is "Desperado"? Law Enforcement has to become much more in tune and educated with the needs (material, PSYCHOLOGICAL, spiritual and cognitive) of the communities it is tasked with patrolling and if they are unable or unwilling to take on the entire scope of their position then they should find work elsewhere. Most police will respond to this by saying that such a comprehensive approach is not in there job description and will have little to no effect on the streets. One must then in reply confront them with the nature of law itself. Law is connected to the mentalities of man. It seeks to control or less invasively patrol the passions and actions of man which stem directly from his mind. And if you cannot fully comprehend the mind of a man as an externality of the environment in which he inhabits then how can you fully understand the mechanics of law itself? Again Law and the mind are like hand and glove. Some cops will say that it is for the courts to decide. However, one must argue back plainly that judges, prison guards and prosecutors don't walk the streets or patrol the beats and they rely on and TRUST police officers and their presupposed understanding of the law to bring cases before them that only meet or exceed the requirements set out by the law. That is why POLICE OFFICERS HAVE TO TESTIFY IN COURT because they are considered to be expert witnesses in terms of criminal justice and are expected to expose the very fine details of active criminality that a DA stuck in an office or a judge stuck behind a bench does not have the time nor mental hard drive space to process thoroughly. Be clear on two things: This is not meant to be a belittling or a rebuke of the police or the letter and spirit of the law. I have 3 siblings with long careers in law enforcement as police officers, correctional officers and sheriffs. This is also not an approval of criminality. I have exponentially many more family and friend who have been involved in the world of crime and it is nothing to brag about or applaud as a successful life to lead. Most of the time it has ended in death or prison or both. Both these institutions are reflections of the human condition and our understandings and misunderstandings of the way the world is "supposed" to work. The death of Sandra Bland is the perfect example of when these two amorphous and wandering institutions get it all the way wrong. Sandra perceived the law enforcement officer to be a law enforcement officer and all that that entails in control of his emotions and strictly subservient to the rule of law when in fact he retreated to criminality and reverted to lawlessness to prosecute what he perceived to be a disrespectful criminal threat in Sandra as opposed to her being a law abiding but pressurized citizen questioning the lawfulness of her stop. Her death in jail is a reflection of the misunderstanding of the mental pressure even the tiniest amount of perceived injustice can do to a person. While I hesitate to judge her cause of death I feel comfortable in saying that if it was suicide it speaks to the depth of the belief we as humans have in right and wrong. Sometimes people would rather die than face the injustices of this world and it doesn't need to be years or decades to decay someone to such a state it can take hours or days. Even seconds. The direct connection between The Law and The Mind is something that needs to taken very seriously by not only police officers but also by the rank and file citizen. The FULL scope of Law and Law Enforcement and Criminality and what effects they all have on the already overly sensitized and tandemically overly desensitized psyches of the communities they inhabit needs to become a dominant issue in culture. So while law enforcement officers may by definition not be our "friends" it might be time that they damn well think about becoming them or at least stray from acting as our enemies. And it might do us well to accept them as "friends" if they honestly extend the offer and not make ourselves enemies to them based on what we see in the trending multimediums as "Brand Cop." Otherwise we together run the risk of giving birth to a new child, one that will feed not on milk but instead off the flesh and blood of its parents.

Sincerely,

Wasalu "Lupe" Jaco
summary:
The letter from Lupe Fiasco explores the complex relationship between law enforcement, the law, criminality, and society as a whole. One key theme that comes through is the idea that the police are not inherently friends or enemies, but rather a reflection of the law itself. The letter also delves into the idea that crime is not always black and white, and can sometimes be a response to perceived injustices or a lack of opportunity within society. The comparison between police officers and criminals as two sides of the same coin highlights the intricate balance between upholding the law and bending it to achieve justice.

Additionally, the letter touches on the idea of mental pressure and the impact that perceived injustice can have on individuals. The tragic case of Sandra Bland serves as a poignant example of how misunderstandings and power dynamics within law enforcement can lead to devastating consequences. The letter calls for a greater understanding of the connections between the law, law enforcement, criminality, and the human mind, emphasizing the need for empathy, communication, and mutual respect between all parties involved.

Overall, the letter encourages readers to consider the complexity of these issues and the importance of addressing them with nuance and compassion. It serves as a powerful reminder of the interconnectedness of law and society, and the profound impact they can have on individuals' lives.

The city is described as both cold and hot, reflecting the emotional turmoil of the protagonist. The act of bending space and time to reach the city suggests a desperation and determination to connect with something or someone significant.

The repeated refrain "we thieves don't die" could be interpreted as a metaphor for resilience and survival in difficult circumstances. The protagonist sees themselves as a thief, someone who is constantly taking risks and breaking boundaries to achieve their goals. The idea of leaving behind something suggests a legacy or impact that remains even after they are gone.

Overall, these lyrics explore themes of longing, escapism, and defiance. The city and the act of thievery serve as metaphors for the protagonist's inner struggles and the lengths they are willing to go to in order to feel alive and connected.

summary:
The lyrics touch on themes of police brutality, racial injustice, revolution, and the complexities of society. Lupe Fiasco uses vivid imagery and metaphors to convey the struggles and challenges faced by marginalized communities, particularly in the context of police violence. The repeated refrain of "beat him in the head, kick him in the neck, beat him on the leg" highlights the physical violence and oppression experienced by individuals at the hands of law enforcement.

The references to historical figures and events, such as Rodney King and the civil rights movement, add depth to the storytelling and show the interconnectedness of past and present injustices. Lupe Fiasco also explores the idea of revolution and the consequences of standing up against oppressive systems, emphasizing that change may come at a cost and that true freedom is not easily won.

The lyrics also delve into the intricacies of society and power dynamics, touching on issues such as celebrity culture, climate change, and cultural identity. Through clever wordplay and complex rhyme schemes, Lupe Fiasco challenges the listener to think critically about the world around them and the need for systemic change. The overarching message seems to be a call to action, urging people to join together in the fight for justice and equality, even if it means sacrificing the comfort of simply "making friends."

Throughout the verses, the artist expresses a sense of superiority and dominance over others in the rap game. They boast about their talent, flow, and ability to outshine their peers. The use of metaphors such as being a "fire flame spitta" and references to weaponry convey a sense of power and aggression in their delivery. 

Additionally, the lyrics touch on themes of spirituality and gratitude, as the artist mentions praying and acknowledging a higher power. There is also a sense of resilience and determination, as the artist vows to continue pursuing success despite any obstacles or doubters.

Overall, the lyrics convey a mix of confidence, bravado, spirituality, and determination, showcasing the artist's mindset and attitude towards their craft and success in the music industry.

The metaphor of the person being compared to sunshine, moonlight, and starry skies highlights the idea of them being a source of light and beauty in the speaker's life. The mention of a castle, dragons, and a knight in shining armor adds a fairy-tale-like element to the song, emphasizing the idea of a magical and romantic connection. The lyrics of "Superstar" by Lupe Fiasco featuring Matthew Santos explore the theme of fame and the pressure that comes with being in the spotlight. The song criticizes the superficial nature of celebrity culture and questions the authenticity of being a superstar. 

Lupe Fiasco reflects on the illusion of fame and the desire for recognition. He discusses the challenges of navigating the music industry and the expectations placed on artists to maintain their image. The song also addresses the idea of being true to oneself and not getting caught up in the hype and glamour of fame.

The lyrics use metaphors such as being on stage under the spotlight, waiting for approval and applause from the audience, to represent the scrutiny and judgment that celebrities face. The references to being a superstar, having cameras and microphones pointed at you, signify the constant surveillance and scrutiny that comes with fame.

Overall, the song conveys a message about staying true to oneself, not getting lost in the trappings of fame, and questioning the superficiality of celebrity culture. It serves as a reminder to not lose sight of one's authenticity and values amidst the pressures of fame.

tite: Life, Death & Love From San Fransisco
lyrics:
She said love is a hard thing

For a real good whiff

She ain't living in a car she just RV-ing
Life on ice like the San Jose Shark team
Hard times, tryna duck em like Darkwing
Known for burning clothes and petty car-keying
And other less harmful skylarking
Bought a bag out of American Rag
A small Chinese-made American flag
Took a dollar bill then split it in half
The picture that she bought wouldn't fit in the cab
On a train trying her best not to live in the past
A bum probably asked could he spit in her ass
And that was it, fits, tantrums random
Helter-Skelter, a world gone Manson
And I'll spare you the details
Dinner is ceviche out of seashells
Annoyed cause her date really can't speak well
But she forced to press on like Lee nails
Next table was abhored by the weed smell
She was done at the moment that the tea fell
A thick wool jacket on a cool night
Unimpressed by poems or the moonlight
Doesn't satisfy like a game of pool might
Thinking "what if Fantasia had a broom strike? "
Tune right out of that school life
Soon as reality became a camera crew and a boom mic
So what do you do like?
She said "absurd last words from a dude off a Zoosk site"
And then left him
Like the Roots left Geffen
And the state Howlin' Wolf left Chess in
Stop to watch flows have an unpaid session on the steps of a Westin
She really need to check in
And to apologize to her best friend
New bras to put her chest in
Love life or deathin...
summary:
The above lyrics convey a sense of struggle, both in love and in life. The speaker describes a woman who is navigating difficult relationships and experiences, from dealing with parole board pardoning to working as a bartender. The lyrics touch on themes of hardship, disillusionment, and the complexities of human connections.

Metaphors such as comparing love to a hard swing, picking flowers like guitar strings, and life behind par illustrate the ups and downs of relationships. The mention of American Rag, splitting a dollar bill in half, and trying to avoid living in the past suggests a sense of fragmentation and a desire to move forward despite challenges. The speaker also references random tantrums, mundane daily experiences, and feeling unimpressed by romantic gestures, hinting at a sense of disillusionment and disconnect.

Overall, the lyrics paint a picture of a woman who is trying to find her way in a world filled with obstacles and disappointments, navigating through love, life, and the complexities of human interactions.

The metaphor of sewing and tailoring throughout the verses could represent the act of creating one's identity and expressing oneself through personal style and artistry. lyrics:
My door

For on the other side is me
And my sword and my armor and my hopes
On me, the cause are hung
On me, are the walls
My doors keep me not safe
My doors protect the ills from me
My door is the last chance for that which reared head and breathed fire and stole joy and ended youth
My door is the scariest of doors
To the malady and the kings
When it opens the world will shake, the hearts will fill
When it opens the winds will come with
And the light will shine off my armor and my sword
And the voices will rise and the calls will become hollas
And the temperature will soar, the arrows will strike me
I will be pierced
I will be overwhelmed
I will break
I will collapse
I will be consumed
But I will regain my footing
I will drag my armor my sword in the weight of the cause
Step by step, until I reach the door
The door of crisis
The door of malady
And I will close it
summary:
The lyrics depict the idea of facing one's fears and challenges, symbolized by the door. The door is described as the scariest place on earth because it represents the unknown and the potential for danger. It also symbolizes the self, with the armor and sword representing strength and protection, and the hopes and dependencies representing responsibilities and burdens. 

The lyrics convey a sense of resilience and determination in the face of adversity. Despite the fear and uncertainty, the narrator is willing to confront what lies beyond the door, knowing that it may bring struggle and hardship. The closing of the door at the end suggests a sense of triumph and overcoming, as the narrator chooses to confront and deal with their challenges rather than being consumed by them.

Overall, the lyrics suggest the importance of facing one's fears and taking on challenges with courage and determination, even when the outcome is uncertain. It portrays the inner strength and resilience needed to navigate through difficult times and emerge stronger on the other side.

The lyrics in this song "Just Might Be OK" by Lupe Fiasco touch upon themes of materialism, superficiality, and manipulation in relationships. The song portrays the narrator as someone who uses his wealth and possessions to attract women and manipulate them for his own benefit. He talks about flaunting his watch, chain, and Range Rover to impress women and get what he wants from them.

The narrator also discusses the idea of playing a role or putting on a facade to deceive others. He admits to pretending to be someone he's not in order to win over women, but ultimately realizes the emptiness of this behavior. The lyrics suggest a sense of disillusionment with materialism and a recognition of the importance of authenticity and self-respect in relationships.

Overall, the song critiques the shallow and transactional nature of some interactions, while also hinting at a desire for genuine connection and honesty. It highlights the contrast between the superficiality of appearances and the deeper complexities of human relationships.

lyrics: Time out, time out, time out! Before we leave can we get Lupe to rap???
summary:
The lyrics "Time out, time out, time out! Before we leave can we get Lupe to rap???" could be interpreted as a request or plea to take a break and not end a situation or event just yet. The repetition of "time out" emphasizes the urgency and importance of pausing before making a final decision or leaving a certain place.

In terms of themes and metaphors, the lyrics could signify the desire to delay a moment of closure or departure, wanting to prolong a certain experience or opportunity. This could reflect a longing to hold on to something meaningful or enjoyable before it comes to an end. The mention of Lupe, possibly referring to a rapper or artist, could suggest a desire for a final performance or expression of creativity before moving on to something new.

Overall, the lyrics convey a sense of hesitation and a need to savor the present moment before moving on to the next chapter. It captures the feeling of wanting to make the most of a situation and not rushing to move forward without fully experiencing it.

The chorus highlights the idea that everyone has their own problems and obstacles to overcome, and the singer encourages empathy and understanding for others' experiences.

The repeated metaphor of "walking in my shoes" symbolizes the unique journey and perspective of the singer. It emphasizes the idea that one can never truly understand another person's struggles unless they have experienced it themselves. The singer is proud of who they are and does not feel the need to change for anyone else.

Overall, the lyrics convey a sense of empowerment and self-assurance, reminding listeners to stay true to themselves and keep moving forward despite the obstacles they may face.

lyrics:
[Verse 1]

They also says, I was more rudderless than a ship
Without a captain adrift
On the ocean of life, no destination in sight
But now I see, what it means to be in need of the preservation of life

[Verse 2]
A glass of water with a goldfish inside
Used to swimming in the river, this a whole different vibe
Feel like a fish outta water, now harbors in new tank
Dressed in camouflage, soldiers in uniforms salute it from the ranks
Like thanks for your service, and everything you do behind the scenes
And beneath the surface, like a disguise
In the distorted reflection of the surface of the fish eyes

[Interlude: Instrumental]
Yeah, yeah, uh, uh
Yeah, yeah

[Verse 3]
Glasses of water, eyes filled with tears
Got the world looking blurry
Like a Monet painting
Not a cloud in the sky
But each cloud of eye of my hard times
And crying will have the whole world raining
Umbrellas provide shelter
Put the tent up
Release the pent-up emotions to feel better
Growing pains, sewing lanes, irrigation is making the fields wetter
That's a glass of water, the scent reminds you of the tap from your childhood home
Like an old friend, you relish the familiar taste
No matter how mundane that it may have been and
The right glass might send you to a past life
Make you want to live your new day like a last night
As you maraud through the weather that you can't see
Stick an umbrella in it if you feelin' fancy, yeah
summary:
The lyrics above talk about the importance of water as a symbol of sustenance, rejuvenation, and life. The glass of water is used metaphorically to represent different aspects of life and human emotions.

In the first verse, the glass of water represents a source of nourishment and guidance, helping the speaker navigate through life's challenges and uncertainties. It symbolizes the realization of the value of self-preservation and the importance of being hydrated in both a physical and metaphorical sense.

In the second verse, the goldfish in the glass of water symbolizes adaptation and resilience. The fish is out of its comfort zone but learns to thrive in its new environment, embodying the idea of embracing change and facing challenges head-on.

The third verse delves into the emotional aspect of water, with tears representing a release of pent-up emotions and a means of finding catharsis. The speaker finds comfort and familiarity in the simple act of drinking a glass of water, connecting it to nostalgic memories and the passage of time.

Overall, the lyrics explore themes of resilience, adaptation, emotional release, and the significance of everyday experiences. The metaphors of water and glasses provide a deeper insight into the complexities of human emotions and the ways in which we navigate through life's ups and downs.

The idea of swallowing the combination and forgetting it could symbolize how individuals conform to society's standards and lose their own identity in the process. The repetition of "he never lies" may suggest a sense of denial or repression within the individual.

The themes of conformity, fear, and loss of self-expression are prominent in these lyrics, as well as a sense of longing for something more authentic or meaningful outside of the confines of the box. The lyrics also touch on the idea of self-destructive behavior and the struggle to break free from destructive habits or patterns.

Overall, the lyrics convey a sense of despair and emptiness that comes from living a life dictated by external forces, and the longing for true freedom and authenticity.

summary:
The lyrics of the song "Battle Scars" by Lupe Fiasco and Guy Sebastian convey the pain and struggle of being in a turbulent and difficult relationship. The metaphor of battle scars represents the emotional wounds and trauma that result from love and heartbreak. The lyrics discuss the constant struggle to keep a relationship together despite the challenges and hardships that come with it. The imagery of being at war with love and facing battles within oneself highlights the internal conflict and emotional toll that love can bring.

The lyrics also touch on themes of resilience, vulnerability, and the struggle to let go of a toxic relationship. The narrator expresses a longing for the pain to heal, but acknowledges that it may never fully go away. The repeated refrain of "These battle scars don't look like they're fading" emphasizes the enduring impact of love and heartbreak.

Overall, the song captures the raw and intense emotions that come with love and relationships, and explores the complexities of trying to navigate through the pain and healing process. It is a poignant reminder of the scars and wounds that love can leave behind, but also a testament to the strength and resilience that can come from facing and overcoming those battles.

The lyrics in this song "Touch the Sky" by Kanye West featuring Lupe Fiasco touch on themes of perseverance, ambition, success, and self-reflection. The chorus and post-chorus emphasize the desire to "touch the sky," which can be interpreted as reaching for one's highest potential and achieving greatness. The verses depict Kanye's journey from humble beginnings to becoming a hip-hop legend, facing challenges, making mistakes, and ultimately finding redemption and success.

There are also themes of self-improvement and growth, as Kanye reflects on his past actions and strives to right his wrongs. The mention of Gucci and Slick Rick represent moments of cultural significance and influence in Kanye's life. Additionally, Lupe Fiasco's verse adds a layer of introspection and clever wordplay, emphasizing the importance of staying true to oneself and continuously improving.

Overall, the song carries a message of resilience, determination, and the pursuit of dreams despite obstacles. It encourages listeners to believe in themselves, overcome setbacks, and strive for greatness.

The lyrics also touch on the internal conflict and inner battles that come with trying to move on and heal from a painful experience.

The references to war, wounds, and fighting convey the intense emotional struggle and the feeling of being at war with love. The lyrics suggest a sense of hopelessness and resignation, as the narrator acknowledges the difficulty of healing from the emotional wounds inflicted by love.

The chorus, “These battle scars, don't look like they're fading, don't look like they're ever going away, they ain't never gonna change” emphasizes the lasting impact of heartache and the difficulty in moving on from a past relationship. The repeated refrain of “Until you tell me it's over” highlights the longing for closure and resolution in the aftermath of a breakup.

Overall, these lyrics delve into the complex emotions and experiences that accompany the end of a relationship, portraying the pain, longing, and struggle to heal and move on.

These lyrics delve into the concept of wealth and how it can sometimes lead individuals to make poor decisions. Rick Ross, Lupe Fiasco, and Wale all share their perspectives on the struggles and challenges that come with wealth and the materialistic desires that can consume people.

One major theme in the lyrics is the idea of poor decision-making among rich individuals. The artists discuss how money and success can lead to a lack of values or morals, causing individuals to prioritize material possessions over important aspects of life such as family, community, and personal growth. This is highlighted through references to drug selling, absent fathers, and the impact of poverty on people's lives.

Lupe Fiasco also touches on the contrast between the desire for material wealth and the importance of community and personal well-being. He expresses the idea that true success goes beyond material possessions and involves taking care of one's health and relationships.

Overall, the lyrics convey a message about the complexities of wealth and how it can both empower and corrupt individuals. The artists highlight the importance of making conscious and responsible decisions, regardless of one's financial status.

The lyrics of the song "Just The Way You Are" by Bruno Mars and Lupe Fiasco carry themes of self-acceptance, inner beauty, and authenticity. The song emphasizes the importance of staying true to oneself and not letting others' opinions or societal pressures change who you are. The artists encourage listeners to embrace their unique qualities and not seek validation from external sources.

Bruno Mars' verses express admiration for a woman's natural beauty and remind her that she doesn't need to change or seek perfection to be loved. He compliments her on her physical features, but also emphasizes that her inner qualities are what truly make her amazing. This reinforces the idea that true beauty comes from within and being yourself is enough.

Lupe Fiasco's verse further reinforces the message of self-acceptance, urging listeners not to get caught up in superficial appearances and to appreciate their inner beauty. He encourages embracing one's authenticity and not conforming to societal standards of beauty.

Overall, the song serves as a reminder to love and appreciate oneself for who they are, both inside and out. It promotes the idea that true beauty lies in being genuine and staying true to oneself, rather than trying to fit a certain mold or seeking validation from others.

These lyrics seem to touch on themes of love, loss, perseverance, and moving on. The chorus and verses depict a sense of moving forward, spreading wings, and flying high, both metaphorically and literally. The idea of not looking down and having an impossible view can symbolize pushing past obstacles and fears to achieve something greater.

The verses from Lupe Fiasco, Kanye West, and Big Sean also explore the complexities of relationships, heartbreak, and the struggle to let go. Each artist presents their own perspective on love and loss, highlighting the emotional turmoil and growth that can come from difficult experiences.

The imagery of flying like an eagle and being a phoenix on fire symbolize the strength and resilience needed to overcome challenges and soar to new heights. The references to aerial views, wings, and flames all reinforce the idea of rising above adversity and embracing change.

Overall, these lyrics convey a message of hope, transformation, and the power of moving forward despite hardships. They encourage listeners to spread their wings, embrace new opportunities, and keep pushing forward towards their dreams.

summary:
The lyrics of this song "I'm On" by several artists such as Lupe Fiasco, Trae Tha Truth, Wale, Wiz Khalifa, and Big Boi touch on themes of success, perseverance, ambition, and self-confidence. The artists talk about their journey from struggling to make it in the music industry to achieving success and recognition. They speak about staying true to themselves, overcoming obstacles, and remaining focused on their goals.

The metaphor of being "on" is used throughout the song to signify being in a position of power, success, and influence. The artists talk about how they have worked hard to get to where they are and are now reaping the rewards of their efforts. They also mention staying true to their roots and not forgetting where they came from, despite their newfound success.

The use of metaphors such as "I'm on like the light on" and "Turn something rough into a diamond" further emphasize the idea of shining bright and making the best of their circumstances. Overall, the song conveys a message of resilience, determination, and staying true to oneself in the face of challenges.

The lyrics discuss the concept of time and the feeling of being too late in various aspects of life. Big Sean reflects on feeling like he's running out of time to achieve his dreams, make things right in relationships, or make a positive impact on the world. He touches on themes of regret, missed opportunities, and the pressure to succeed before it's too late. Lupe Fiasco adds to this theme by discussing the pressure to be on time and the importance of not missing opportunities.

The metaphor of time is used throughout the song, with references to clocks, alarms, and being late. The lyrics also touch on the idea of constantly feeling behind and trying to catch up, whether it's in personal relationships, career goals, or societal expectations. Ultimately, the song conveys a sense of urgency and the desire to make a meaningful impact before it's too late.

summary:
The lyrics in this song convey a message of self-reflection, societal critique, and a call to action. The chorus speaks to coming back stronger and more powerful, ready to face challenges and relapse into old habits. The references to materialism, greed, and the pursuit of money highlight the negative influences in society that can lead people astray.

The verses touch on themes of struggle, resilience, and the desire for success. Big KRIT emphasizes the importance of staying true to oneself and not getting lost in the pursuit of material possessions or societal expectations. He urges listeners to prioritize their mental and emotional well-being over material wealth.

The bridge with Lupe Fiasco introduces a more aggressive and destructive perspective, advocating for violence, substance abuse, and selfishness. This contrasts with the earlier themes of self-awareness and reflection, showing the potential consequences of giving in to negative influences and losing sight of one's values.

Overall, the lyrics in this song highlight the struggles and obstacles faced by individuals in a complex and often corrupt society. It calls for self-awareness, critical thinking, and a sense of purpose in order to navigate through the challenges and find success on one's own terms.

summary:
The lyrics convey a deep introspection and reflection on the complexities of human nature, inner turmoil, and social issues. Lupe Fiasco explores the duality of his own thoughts and emotions, as well as the struggles of society as a whole. He touches on themes of balance, transformation, and the constant battle between good and evil.

The mention of figures like Martin Luther King, Gil Scott-Heron, and James Baldwin highlights the influence of history and social justice on his perspective. He also references the power of words and music to inspire change and challenge societal norms.

Metaphors such as “ninja turtles pouring out of manholes” and “a boomerang minus Halle Barry and Eddie” bring a sense of surrealism and creativity to his storytelling. The imagery of cutting off from negative influences and striving for peace and self-improvement is a recurring theme throughout the lyrics.

Overall, the lyrics suggest a deep sense of purpose and a desire for positive change, both personally and in the world at large. They invite listeners to contemplate their own inner struggles and the collective challenges we face as a society.

These lyrics depict the struggles and experiences of living a rough and tough life, often referred to as the life of a "savage." The artists, RondoNumbaNine and Lupe Fiasco, talk about going through difficult situations, witnessing violence and adversity, and maintaining a tough exterior while still striving for success. They talk about the importance of staying loyal to their crew, seeking success and material possessions, and dealing with the constant threat of danger and violence in their environment.

Additionally, references to specific events and people, like "Rip D-Thang," add a personal touch to the lyrics and highlight the impact of loss and tragedy in their lives.

Overall, these lyrics capture the raw and gritty reality of life in their world, where survival and success often go hand in hand with violence and struggle.

Each artist in the song expresses their unique perspective on life and their journey to success. Some of the major themes include self-belief, overcoming obstacles, and staying true to oneself despite criticism or doubt.

Throughout the lyrics, there are references to inner strength and resilience, as well as the importance of staying focused and determined in the face of challenges. The artists also highlight the idea of being true to one's own artistry and not compromising their vision for the sake of commercial success.

Metaphors such as "beaming" and "aura" suggest a sense of radiance and positivity, indicating a strong sense of self-confidence and inner light. The references to various cultural and personal experiences add depth and complexity to the lyrics, showing the multifaceted nature of the artists' identities and their creative journeys. 

Overall, the lyrics convey a sense of empowerment, creativity, and individuality, encouraging listeners to embrace their unique voice and pursue their dreams with passion and authenticity.

summary:
The lyrics of "Kick, Push" by Lupe Fiasco and Drake explore themes of rebellion, self-expression, perseverance, and finding one's place in the world. The song tells the story of a young skateboarder who finds solace and freedom in skating, despite facing obstacles and criticism from others. 

The act of skating is portrayed as a form of escapism and a way to break free from societal constraints. The skateboard becomes a symbol of personal freedom and individuality, as the protagonist and his crew navigate through streets and skate parks, defying authority and pursuing their passion for skating. 

Metaphorically, the skateboard can be seen as a vehicle for self-discovery and empowerment. The act of "kick, push, coast" not only refers to the physical motions of skating but also symbolizes the journey of pushing forward, overcoming challenges, and finding moments of peace and clarity. 

Overall, the lyrics highlight the importance of following one's passions, staying true to oneself, and embracing the rebellious spirit that drives us to pursue our dreams, even in the face of adversity.

The lyrics in this song "I'm Beamin'" by Lupe Fiasco and Pharrell Williams touch on various themes such as success, struggle, perseverance, and self-confidence. Lupe Fiasco raps about the challenges he has faced and overcome to achieve success in his career. He uses metaphors and wordplay to convey his journey from the underground music scene to soaring like a G4, symbolizing his rise to fame and recognition.

The chorus, sung by Pharrell Williams, emphasizes the idea of not letting others bring you down or disrespect you, no matter how successful you become. He expresses confidence in his abilities and achievements, acknowledging that not everyone will understand or appreciate his success, but that won't deter him from continuing to thrive.

Overall, the lyrics in this song encourage listeners to stay true to themselves, persevere through challenges, and not let negativity or jealousy affect their journey towards success. It's a message of empowerment and self-assurance, celebrating one's accomplishments and resilience in the face of adversity.

Dee-1, Big Krit, and Lupe Fiasco all share their perspectives on these topics, emphasizing the importance of staying true to oneself, seeking forgiveness, and standing up against those who oppress or harm others.

Dee-1 talks about the importance of staying authentic and not compromising one's values for material gain. He also highlights the ongoing struggle between good and evil, advocating for unity and love over hate. Big Krit addresses the impact of systemic racism and economic disparities, urging listeners to rise above their circumstances and support each other. Lupe Fiasco touches on themes of perseverance and self-expression, emphasizing the need to challenge societal norms and strive for personal growth.

Overall, the lyrics of the song convey a message of resilience, faith, and solidarity in the face of adversity. The artists encourage listeners to reflect on their actions, seek forgiveness, and work towards a better future for themselves and their communities.

Overall, the lyrics convey a sense of confidence, determination, and a relentless drive to succeed in the face of obstacles. They also celebrate their achievements and status in the music industry, showcasing their skills and talent as artists.

The lyrics in the song "Forever" by Chris Brown featuring Lil Wayne and Lupe Fiasco touch on themes of love, passion, and living in the moment. The artists express a sense of urgency and excitement about seizing the moment and embracing the connection they have with their partners. The idea of being on the dance floor and having a night of fun and love symbolizes the desire to fully immerse oneself in the present and savor every moment.

The song also explores the idea of unity and partnership, with lyrics about being together as a couple and facing any challenges or negativity that may come their way. The metaphor of dancing represents the joy and freedom that can be found in a relationship, as well as the idea of moving together in sync and harmony.

Overall, the lyrics emphasize the importance of cherishing love, embracing the present, and finding happiness in each other's company. The artists convey a sense of passion, unity, and celebration of the magic of being in love.

The above lyrics touch on themes of storytelling, perseverance, sacrifice, and consequences. The artists discuss the power of using words and imagery to paint a picture in the listener's mind, showcasing their storytelling abilities. They also delve into the struggles and hardships faced by individuals in difficult situations, such as the young boy dealing with older criminals and the man making risky decisions to secure a better life for his loved ones.

The lyrics also explore the consequences of one's actions and the sacrifices that may need to be made in pursuit of a goal. Whether it's the man risking his life for a chance at a better future or the space captain making a heroic last stand, the artists highlight the importance of facing challenges head-on and being willing to make sacrifices for what one believes in.

Overall, the lyrics convey a sense of resilience, determination, and the power of storytelling to convey deep emotions and messages. They use metaphors and vivid imagery to bring the listener into the narrative and evoke strong emotions and reactions.

These lyrics speak to the struggle of pursuing one's dreams and passions in the face of adversity and societal pressure to conform. The song emphasizes the importance of staying true to oneself and not letting others dictate or discourage you from following your own path.

The chorus expresses a sense of determination and defiance against those who doubt or criticize the individual's aspirations. The repeated refrain of "Gonna be somebody" and "Gonna be someone" reinforces a sense of self-belief and confidence in achieving success despite obstacles.

The verses delve into the challenges and criticisms faced by the speaker as they pursue their creative endeavors. They talk about the pressure to conform to societal norms and expectations, as well as the resistance and skepticism encountered from others. The metaphor of having a "chip on both sides of their neck" symbolizes the burden and judgment carried by individuals trying to carve out their own identity.

Overall, the song celebrates resilience, perseverance, and the courage to defy societal norms in pursuit of one's dreams. It acknowledges the struggle and the doubters, but ultimately inspires listeners to push forward and prove their worth through determination and hard work.

Papoose addresses the deaths of soldiers, the aftermath of 9/11, and the challenges faced by African Americans. Lupe Fiasco uses powerful metaphors to describe the destructive nature of the entertainment industry and the impact it has on society. Styles P delves into themes of street life, violence, and the need for self-awareness and resilience in a harsh environment.

The artists use vivid imagery and wordplay to showcase their lyrical prowess and highlight important issues affecting their communities. The cypher format allows for a free-flowing exchange of ideas and perspectives, creating a powerful and thought-provoking piece of music.

These lyrics touch on themes of perseverance, resilience, and overcoming the challenges and chaos of the world. The chorus emphasizes the importance of maintaining strength and determination in the face of adversity, even when things are difficult and the world seems insane.

Snoop Dogg's verse talks about standing tall and maintaining a sense of power and confidence, even in difficult situations. He references struggles and obstacles, but also hints at finding success and wealth in the midst of it all.

The mention of Kimi Räikkönen's Lotus position and the Cathouse Christmas party suggest a blend of high pressure situations and celebration, reflecting the ups and downs of life.

Overall, these lyrics convey a message of strength, resilience, and determination in the face of the unpredictable and tumultuous world. They encourage the listener to persevere and stay true to themselves, no matter what challenges come their way.

summary:
The lyrics seem to be discussing the idea of balance and navigating through life's highs and lows. The artists use the metaphor of walking on a tightrope to represent this balance, where one must tip carefully to stay upright. The tightrope can symbolize the challenges and obstacles one may face in life, and how important it is to maintain equilibrium to continue moving forward.

B.o.B talks about his unique approach to music and how he thrives off of haters and obstacles, using them as motivation to keep going. He mentions breaking barriers and not apologizing for his prophecies, indicating a sense of confidence and determination in his artistry.

Lupe Fiasco discusses the concept of following traditional norms and then breaking free from them to think outside the box. He mentions dropping out of math class and surpassing traditional thinking, embodying a sense of rebelliousness and creativity in his approach.

Janelle Monáe adds her perspective on staying true to oneself and not conforming to expectations. She talks about being unpredictable like the weather and standing tall as an underdog, emphasizing the importance of staying grounded and balanced amidst external pressures.

Overall, the lyrics convey a message of resilience, creativity, and staying true to oneself while navigating through life's challenges and uncertainties. The artists encourage listeners to find their own balance, tip carefully on the tightrope, and keep moving forward in the face of adversity.

Lupe Fiasco's verse highlights the feelings of hesitation and fear of rejection that can come with pursuing a romantic interest. Verbal's verse adds a layer of admiration and respect for the person he is drawn to, emphasizing her beauty and sophistication. He grapples with the idea of taking a chance and reaching out to her, but feels intimidated by the potential challenges and obstacles that may come with it.

The lyrics above primarily focus on themes of success, confidence, and attracting the attention of others, particularly women. The artists, Lupe Fiasco and Chris Brown, boast about their wealth, style, and popularity, emphasizing that they don't need anyone else's approval or validation. They convey a sense of self-assurance and independence, rejecting the idea of wanting someone else's girlfriend but acknowledging that women are drawn to them.

The metaphor of instant replay and instant rebate is used to highlight the constant cycle of winning and achieving success in their lives. The reference to a car show and model-like women further emphasizes the luxury lifestyle they lead. Chris Brown's chorus and verses specifically focus on not wanting someone else's girlfriend but acknowledging that she is attracted to him. The metaphor of "la-la-la" represents a carefree attitude and perhaps the intoxicating allure that the artists have on others.

Lupe Fiasco's verse adds a unique perspective as he contrasts his clean, classy style with the perceived lack of sophistication in others' choices, highlighting his superior taste and intellect. The mention of Jean Grey, a powerful and intelligent character from X-Men, further underscores his confidence and intellect.

Overall, the lyrics convey a sense of pride, success, and a carefree attitude towards relationships and external validation. The artists assert their dominance and individuality while also acknowledging the attention they receive from others.

The lyrics seem to be describing the experience of driving around in a flashy car with 22-inch rims or larger, known as "swanging" in Southern hip-hop culture. The use of candy paint and references to different colors and types of drugs suggest a lifestyle of luxury, excess, and danger.

The song also highlights the pride and identity that come with representing different regions of the United States, such as the Dirty South and Chicago. Bun B and Lupe Fiasco both assert their roots and connections to their respective cities, showcasing their loyalty and authenticity in the rap game.

There is also a theme of unity and collaboration in the song, with multiple artists coming together to celebrate their individual successes and contributions to the rap industry. The references to other artists and their labels show respect and acknowledgment of the community and relationships within the hip-hop world.

Overall, the lyrics convey a sense of confidence, swagger, and camaraderie among the artists, while also touching on themes of materialism, street life, and regional pride.

[Hook]

[Verse 5: Lowkey]

Cause the drones are still flying over Pashtunistan

[Hook]

[Obama]

The Jonas Brothers are here

Sasha and Malia are huge fans

I have two words for you: PREDATOR DRONES
You will never see it coming
(Audience Laughter)

summary:
The lyrics presented above touch on themes of political disillusionment, racism, imperialism, and the betrayal of promises by those in power, specifically focusing on the Obama administration. The artists express their frustration with the status quo and the lack of real change brought about by the first black president. The lyrics criticize Obama for continuing the destructive policies of his predecessors, including military intervention in foreign countries and the use of drone strikes.

The artists also highlight the influence of the Western power structure and its exploitation of resources in other countries. They criticize the hypocrisy of American ideals of freedom and liberty, pointing out the systemic inequality and discrimination faced by marginalized communities.

Overall, the lyrics convey a sense of urgency for revolution and change, calling for people to be actively involved in challenging the oppressive systems in place. They emphasize the need for accountability and transparency from those in power, and urge listeners to question the narratives fed to them by the mainstream media.

All my gangster friends

New York and Hollywood
We all want the same thing...
summary:
The lyrics in the song "We Want The Same Thing" by Kevin Michael and Lupe Fiasco touch on several major themes such as equality, unity, and the desire for change. The song highlights the idea that regardless of our backgrounds or social status, deep down we all want the same things in life - love, acceptance, and opportunity.

The lyrics also delve into the disparity between the ideal world we imagine where everyone is treated equally and the harsh reality of the world we live in where not everyone has the same opportunities. The verses talk about the need for change and making a difference in society by taking action and thinking outside the box.

The collaboration between Kevin Michael and Lupe Fiasco in the song brings a powerful message of unity and the importance of coming together to create a better world for everyone. The metaphor of different groups such as gangsters, skaters, DJs, and Jesus freaks all wanting the same thing emphasizes the universality of human desires and the need to overcome barriers and stereotypes.

Overall, the song "We Want The Same Thing" encourages listeners to reflect on the common values and dreams that connect us all, and to strive towards creating a more inclusive and equal society for everyone.

These lyrics seem to paint a picture of a dangerous and dark world where violence and survival are key themes. The references to zombies and horror movie characters suggest a sense of being hunted or at risk, with the need to constantly be on guard and prepared to defend oneself. The idea of "zombie land" could symbolize a place where people are willing to do whatever it takes to survive, even if it means resorting to violence or unethical behavior.

The repeated mentions of shooting someone in the head to ensure they are really dead could represent the idea of being thorough and making sure to eliminate any threats completely. The imagery of zombies coming back to life even after being shot in the arm reinforces the idea of resilience and the need to be vigilant in a dangerous world.

The lyrics also touch on themes of paranoia, mistrust, and a sense of chaos or lawlessness. The references to crime, drug addiction, and police presence contribute to a sense of a society on the brink of collapse. The overall tone of the lyrics seems to be dark and intense, with a sense of urgency and survival instincts at play.

Overall, these lyrics seem to convey a sense of danger, survival, and the harsh realities of life in a hostile environment. The use of horror movie references and vivid imagery helps to create a haunting and suspenseful atmosphere, painting a picture of a world where one must constantly be on guard and willing to do whatever it takes to stay alive.

The above lyrics seem to highlight the importance of sticking to the basics, or the fundamentals, in life. This can be seen in the repeated references to keeping it real, having chill, having money, and following the G-code. The lyrics suggest that staying true to oneself and focusing on essential values and principles is key to success and survival.

The idea of fundamentals is also applied to different aspects of life, such as in relationships (giving someone fundamentals if they lack chill), in money management (sticking to fundamentals if you don't have money), and in personal conduct (keeping it a hundred, or being honest and authentic).

There is a strong emphasis on authenticity, integrity, and self-awareness throughout the lyrics. The references to guns and violence may symbolize the harsh realities of life and the need to navigate these challenges with a strong moral foundation. The mention of potential and credentials suggests that embracing the fundamentals can lead to growth and success.

Overall, the lyrics encourage listeners to stay true to themselves, focus on what truly matters, and navigate life's challenges with integrity and authenticity.

The lyrics also touch on the idea of being reckless and defying death, with references to dangerous situations and risky behavior. However, there is also a sense of hope and redemption, as the song talks about getting a helping hand and seeing clearly despite difficulties. The chorus emphasizes the idea that anyone can reach for their dreams and find support along the way.

Overall, the song conveys a message of perseverance, courage, and the importance of taking risks in order to achieve success. It encourages listeners to keep moving forward, even when faced with challenges, and to seek out opportunities for growth and self-discovery.

These lyrics seem to be exploring the complexity of a relationship that may have ended or is on the verge of ending, yet both parties are struggling to let go. The idea of dancing and running even when the party is over and the race is done could symbolize the futile efforts to hold onto something that has already reached its end.

The metaphor of trying to "pull the trigger" could represent the difficulty of making the final decision to end the relationship and move on. The repetition of "linger" throughout the chorus emphasizes the lingering feelings and emotions that both individuals are experiencing, unable to fully let go.

The verse by Lupe Fiasco adds another layer to the song, discussing the idea of memories and emotions that continue to exist even after a relationship has ended. The mention of ghosts and haunted houses suggests that these lingering feelings can haunt us even after we have physically moved on.

Overall, the lyrics convey a sense of struggle, confusion, and emotional conflict that often accompany the end of a relationship. There is a sense of longing and uncertainty, with both individuals grappling with their feelings and unable to fully let go.

The mention of being pulverized into dust and the poltergeist rising up could symbolize the destructive nature of seeking pleasure at the expense of authenticity.

The chorus highlights the idea that sometimes pleasure can be painful, and the confusion that arises when one is unaware of the true impact of their actions on others.

The artists are expressing their determination to keep pushing forward despite the obstacles they face. Trae talks about feeling overwhelmed by distractions and challenges, but still fighting for success and stability, particularly for his family. He discusses the constant pressure and scrutiny he faces, but remains focused on his goals.

Lupe Fiasco's verse delves into themes of inequality, injustice, and invisibility. He references historical events like the Tuskegee Airmen and the Tuskegee Syphilis Study to highlight the ongoing struggles faced by Black communities. He discusses the challenges of being a Black man in a society that marginalizes and mistreats him, yet he remains defiant and determined to overcome these obstacles.

Overall, the lyrics reflect a sense of resilience, strength, and determination in the face of adversity. The artists use metaphors and vivid imagery to convey the hardships they face, but also show their resolve to keep fighting and striving for success. It's a powerful message of resilience and perseverance in the face of adversity.

The chorus emphasizes the uniqueness and greatness of the Chicago Bulls, highlighting them as the one and only team. The verses, particularly by Lupe Fiasco, showcase the pride and passion of the fans for the team, highlighting their loyalty and dedication throughout the years.

The lyrics also contain metaphorical references, such as comparing the city to a "mansion" and referencing the team's championship success by mentioning the banners and statue outside the stadium. The lyrics evoke a sense of unity and community among Bulls fans, emphasizing the shared experience of supporting the team and celebrating their victories.

Overall, the song captures the excitement and nostalgia of being a fan of the Chicago Bulls, as well as the pride and love for the city of Chicago itself. It serves as a tribute to the team's history, success, and the enduring loyalty of their fans.

The song touches on themes of perseverance, self-worth, and the power of dreams. Despite facing challenges or feeling overlooked, the lyrics emphasize the importance of finding joy and beauty in the small things. The references to diamonds shining in the night sky and the world as a million star motel speak to finding light and beauty even in the darkest of times.

The collaboration between Lupe Fiasco, Nikki Jean, and Black Thought adds layers of depth to the lyrics, highlighting the importance of community, support, and finding inspiration in the world around us. Overall, the song encourages listeners to see the beauty in life, appreciate the little things, and keep dreaming regardless of circumstances.

summary:
The above lyrics depict a gritty and violent urban environment where gun violence and gang activity are prevalent. The hook emphasizes the finality and inevitability of death when faced with gunfire, highlighting the harsh reality of living in such a dangerous setting.

The verses explore themes of survival, loyalty, and the consequences of living a life of crime. Mikkey Halsted's verses paint a picture of a young individual caught up in a cycle of violence and crime, feeling like there is no way out and needing to constantly be armed for protection. The mention of specific locations and gang affiliations adds to the authenticity of the storytelling.

Lupe Fiasco's verse adds a layer of reflection and regret as he describes trying to save a young man's life as a paramedic, ultimately failing in his efforts. The metaphor of the grim reaper reaching for him and the reference to Muhammad Ali suggest themes of mortality, fighting against inevitability, and the fleeting nature of life.

Overall, the lyrics evoke a sense of hopelessness, desperation, and the harsh realities of living in a violent urban environment. The use of vivid imagery and metaphorical language creates a powerful and thought-provoking narrative about the consequences of violence and the fragility of life.

The lyrics of this song "Didn't You Know" by Joe Budden, Yummy Bingham, Quana, and Lupe Fiasco depict themes of love, loyalty, and devotion. The verses express the deep connection and commitment between two individuals in a relationship, highlighting the importance of trust and understanding. There is also a sense of surprise and realization in the lyrics, as the singers reflect on how their love has transformed their lives and how their partner's love has had a profound impact on them.

The chorus repeatedly asks "Didn't you know what my love would do to you?" implying the transformative power of love and how it can change someone's perspective and priorities. The song also touches on the idea of being surprised by the depth of feelings and emotions that can be evoked by love.

In Lupe Fiasco's verse, he addresses the realization that love has changed him and made him see things in a different light. He acknowledges the shift in his identity and priorities, showing vulnerability and growth through love.

Overall, the lyrics convey a sense of appreciation and gratitude for the love and connection shared between two people, emphasizing the transformative and powerful nature of love.

The lyrics seem to explore themes of feeling like an outsider in society, not fitting in, and being pushed to the outskirts. The repeated reference to being "radioactive" and "sociopathic" could suggest feeling like an outcast or being seen as dangerous or harmful by those in power. The idea of a "critical mass" could represent a breaking point or a tipping point where things need to change in order to push back against the oppressive forces at play.

The lyrics also touch on consumerism and how society encourages us to buy more and conform to certain standards. The idea of being on the edge and blending out could symbolize a desire to break free from societal norms and expectations.

Overall, the lyrics convey a sense of frustration and defiance against the systems that seek to keep individuals down and control them. The repetition of certain phrases and use of metaphorical language adds to the intensity and emotion of the song.
